TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Communications guarantee this House that neither he and his office, nor Senator Collins and his office, nor the Prime Minister and his office were forewarned by senior executives of the television industry that the tendering process for satellite pay TV licences would end up in the shambles that it has? Can the Minister confirm that the decision to drop a deposit requirement for the tendering process was the result of a deliberate government policy based on a fear that there would be an inadequate number of applicants for the licences?

—I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his question. In relation to the first part of the question, my office was not informed because I was not the Minister at that time; so, naturally, I would not be informed. In relation to the second part of the question, we have already explained in this House that there was a deficiency in the process. That deficiency will be fixed by legislation. That legislation is currently before the Parliament and we hope the Opposition will support it.

—Can the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories inform the House of the Government's position on the possible resumption of commercial whaling and the establishment of a Southern Ocean whale sanctuary?

—I thank the honourable member for his question and for his continuing interest in matters of the environment. The 45th annual meeting of the International Whaling Commission is being held this week in Japan. Australia takes to that meeting a very clear and unequivocal position. We oppose all commercial whaling and support worldwide protection of all whales and dolphins. We also support the French proposal for a whale sanctuary in all the Southern Ocean south of 40 degrees.

PARA.TAB: There has been a great deal of media speculation about the possibility of the International Whaling Commission supporting the resumption of some commercial whaling. I wish to assure this Parliament that, if such a proposal is put to a vote, Australia will oppose it. We will continue to lead the push to maintain the global moratorium put in place in 1985-86 and I am confident that we will get enough support from other countries to ensure that that ban remains.

There has been quite a lot of interest and support for the French sanctuary proposal for the Southern Ocean. Australia, of course, fully supports that proposal but, unfortunately, I am not confident that it will receive the 75 per cent majority needed for it to be implemented this year. If that proposal is defeated—and obviously I hope that it will not be—I and the Government are determined that Australia will lead the campaign to ensure that it is successful next year.

Our job will be to make sure that the proposal is kept alive and refined to secure the support of enough countries at the next meeting. If this is the case, we will be seeking International Whaling Commission agreement for further work to be done on the sanctuary proposal, including the development of a timetable for its implementation and agreement on management issues. Australia will offer to host an intercessional planning meeting to facilitate that work.

Australia has always taken a leading role on this issue of protection of whales and dolphins and we will continue to do so. Once again, there is significant international pressure to allow limited commercial whaling of some species and we think it is absolutely critical that Australia keeps the position it has and absolutely holds firm to that moratorium.

I wish to assure the House and the people of Australia that this Government will continue to be at the forefront of efforts to secure the worldwide protection of these magnificent creatures and that we will do everything in our power to ensure the eventual establishment of a secure haven in the Southern Ocean.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Can the Minister inform the House of the take-up rate of school leavers by universities this year? How does that take-up rate compare with previous years? What is the sectoral balance between universities and TAFE colleges?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. On the matters raised by the honourable member, there is basically some very good news in the statistics that have come through. Total enrolments for 1993 have risen to 583,000, an increase of 20,000, or four per cent, on 1992. That reflects growth of 40 per cent in the system since 1988 when the Government signalled its intention to significantly expand the higher education system. Total commencements in 1993 are 218,000, which is up four per cent. It is good to see that school leaver commencements have risen to 69,000 in 1993, an increase of five per cent over 1992.

PARA.TAB: I think it reflects the fact that the majority of institutions have recognised the importance of providing greater opportunities for school leavers to go on to higher education. I think that bespeaks very well of the activities of the previous Minister for higher education in his efforts last year to encourage the universities to up their percentage of school leaver intake. The Government also assisted that by providing some 11,000 additional places.

Last year the school retention rates were substantially increased to some 77 per cent, and we have about 36 per cent of that group of year 12 high school leavers finding their way into the tertiary system. That is really where the numbers ought to be—about 36 to 40 per cent. The recent Finn study outlined that as an appropriate level of participation in the higher education system and encouraged the Government, having reached that level, to ensure opportunities were available for others in vocational education and other aspects of training, which, of course, the Government is doing. There was a very substantial increase last year too in the opportunities available for young people to attend vocational education.

Some comparative statistics are quite interesting as far as our higher education system is concerned. I mentioned the figure of 583,000. Of course, about 550,000 of those enrolments are Australians. If we take the equivalent figures in the United Kingdom, for example, there are some 760,000 students in institutions equivalent to our universities. But the United Kingdom has a population about four times larger than ours. If it had our participation rates in higher education it would be looking at about 2 1/2 million students in British universities. By contrast, were we in the United Kingdom's situation, we would have about 200,000 students in our universities.

That is a reflection of the extraordinary extent to which the Government has been prepared to invest in the development of our higher education system, which is producing those statistics. There are greater opportunities available to young people in this country for higher education than is the case in virtually any other member country of the OECD.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask the Minister: will he reconfirm that it remains the Government's commitment to reduce the Budget deficit to one per cent of GDP by 1996-97? Will he also confirm that target will not be achieved through either the introduction of new taxes or through increases in existing taxes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first part of the question is yes, it is the Government's intention to achieve a Budget deficit of one per cent of GDP by 1996-97. The Government has made that declaration many times, and it adheres to that objective. It is important to do that because, as we all realise, Australia has, in relation to its economic problems, a considerable deficiency in relation to its saving efforts. A major reason for that has been that, with the economic cycle, we have had a considerable amount of public dissaving. In the medium term, it is important for us to address that so that the public dissaving is reduced and the national savings effort is improved.

PARA.TAB: The Government accepts, therefore, that it is important for us to have a fiscal objective which gives us that savings outcome. It recognises that if that is not the case, then the balance of payments current account problem will remain a severe one for the future and will constrain growth. So it is important for us to do it. How we get to that is a matter for the Government to decide in its Budget considerations. The Government has made it clear in statements in the past by the Treasurer that in relation to taxation it does not intend to increase the overall burden of taxation. The Treasurer made that quite clear in a statement to this House on 16 September in which he said that we would not increase the overall burden of taxation.
He also said that we would not introduce a broad based consumption tax, unlike the Opposition which wanted to impose a $20 billion tax on the whole of Australia. He also said:

ANSWER.PARA: We will continue to design tax policy to support saving and investment, responding as necessary to new opportunities and changing circumstances.

At no stage have we said that we are not going to change any tax at any time. It is part of the Government's considerations in the Budget preparation process to address both sides of the Budget, outlays and taxes, and just how that comes out will be seen in the Budget.

—Can the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services inform the House of the progress of the Government's social justice strategy for Australians with disabilities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: HOUSING, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND COMMUNITY SERVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question. There are few areas of the Government's responsibilities that more typify its commitment to social justice than the area of disabilities. Honourable members will recall that last year the Government passed disability discrimination legislation ensuring that over time we will be able to remove areas of discrimination in Australia where it exists within the Commonwealth Government and in terms of our national responsibilities. Honourable members would also be aware that we will very soon reach agreement with each of the States by means of the Commonwealth-State disability agreement, which will provide ongoing guarantees of funding and a much clearer outline of Commonwealth and State responsibility in the area of disability. It will also enable us to build on our commitments under the Disability Services Act to ensure that, even in very difficult economic circumstances, there are more opportunities made available for those with disabilities to participate in the work force.

PARA.TAB: Expenditure on the disabilities services program has increased by 136 per cent from $207 million in 1985-86 to $489,000 million in 1992-93 and services have increased from 1,551 to 2,300, or by 48 per cent. The number of people assisted by the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service has risen from 15,000 in 1988-89 to an estimated 32,000 in 1992-93, an increase of 102 per cent.

A very high proportion—about 50 per cent—of clients being cared for or being counselled by the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service have effectively achieved full-time or part-time employment. Some 82 per cent of people completing programs in the special psychiatric rehabilitation units, which the Government set up in 1991, are now employed. In a week in which we are celebrating national rehabilitation, a commitment to rehabilitation in the Australian community, the Government is able to report considerable progress in achieving its objective.

Australia has a very strong reputation internationally for the reforms that have been carried out in recent years. Few other countries have such a record in developing integrated services for those with disabilities. Few other countries have a record comparable to Australia in developing overall national policy, translating that policy into cooperation with the States, establishing new services, and encouraging thousands of Australians, who otherwise would have been excluded from the work force, to take their place in society through employment, to be independent and to have a better quality of life.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Could the Minister inform the House of progress in efforts to stop over-fishing of the important southern bluefin tuna species?

—I thank the honourable member for Eden-Monaro for his question. He is a member who has had a long-term interest in the future of the Australian fishing industry. It affects his own electorate very strongly. The southern bluefin tuna is an industry that is very important to Australia since last year it earned $180 million in export earnings. It is very important, therefore, for Australia that only sustainable catches are taken each year. Southern bluefin tuna are distributed throughout the Indian and Southern oceans and in the past they have been heavily over-fished, which is not in the long-term interests of Australia or many other nations. The result has been that since those stocks have been depleted, the future of the species and of the industry are under threat.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to say that in recent years New Zealand, Japan and Australia have worked together to reduce catches to sustainable levels. Since 1986 annual quotas have been set for southern bluefin tuna, and they have been agreed to voluntarily. I am pleased to announce to the House that we will go a step further when later today my colleague the honourable Minister for Primary Industries and Energy will sign the International Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna with the Japanese and New Zealand governments. The convention will provide a legally binding framework and will include mandatory allocation of the total allowable catch. The honourable member for Higgins will be interested to know that this will be the first convention signed by Australia to control fishing for southern bluefin tuna, not only in Australia's national fishing zones, but on the high seas as well.

The convention will create a commission for the conservation of southern bluefin tuna which will meet each year to determine the management measures for the fishery. I am also pleased to say that Australia has offered to have the commission's headquarters established in Australia. With the large quota reductions in recent years Australia's southern bluefin tuna industry has had to undergo a major restructuring, which has not been easy. It has included the conversion of vessels for long-line fishing to increase export returns from the lucrative Japanese sashimi market, which I know you, Mr Speaker, are very keen to encourage.

The international convention to be signed by the Minister later today will lay the basis for the further development of this high value export market for Australia. The convention illustrates that, with the cooperative approach to resource management of this Government, valuable natural resources can be protected while at the same time providing a significant economic benefit for Australia.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Justice. Is the Minister for Justice aware of concerns in the Victorian legal aid community that the Crimes (Criminal Trials) Bill introduced by the Victorian Attorney-General, Jan Wade, represents an attack on the independence of the Victorian Legal Aid Commission and places it in an impossible financial position? What action will be taken in relation to the Bill?

—All States are, of course, concerned about the implications of the Dietrich decision. That decision has major financial impacts on the provision of legal aid because, in short, it treats the provision of legal aid as essential for a fair trial in serious criminal matters. The response of the Victorian Attorney-General has caused some concern. I wrote to her on 3 May to raise those concerns with her.

PARA.TAB: While I am sympathetic to the need for all governments to respond to the funding issues that the Dietrich case causes for the States and the Commonwealth, a working party has been established by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General which will report to the next meeting in June, then the Commonwealth and the States will be able to take a national approach in relation to the Dietrich matter.

The Crimes (Criminal Trials) Bill undermines this consultative process in which the Attorney-General of Victoria has agreed to participate. Under the proposed legislation, in certain circumstances, courts in Victoria will be able to order the provision of legal aid from the Legal Aid Commission on terms specified by the courts. What is particularly alarming about this matter is that a judge would be able to make that order on the basis that an accused is unable to provide the full cost of obtaining private legal representation. That would have the effect of undermining the independence of the Legal Aid Commission of Victoria and therefore put at serious risk the Commonwealth funds provided to the Victorian commission under the Commonwealth-State agreements.

The legislation will take away from the commission the power responsibly to manage its own budget. There is no doubt that were this legislation to be enacted, considerably more legal aid funds would be diverted away from family and civil law matters to meet the cost of legal aid ordered by the court for criminal matters. The Commonwealth provides a very substantial component of funding for all legal aid commissions, and we cannot simply stand idly by if the outcome is to apply most of that funding to matters which ordinarily would have been the responsibility of the States.

Whilst the Victorian Legal Aid Commission is being told to administer a scheme where it will have no control over expenditure, the Victorian Government is also threatening to remove up to $2 million in funding, which places the commission in an almost impossible situation. I now reiterate my invitation to the Victorian Attorney-General to discuss the matter as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Prime Minister aware of reports today referring to the fact that Australia is among the lowest taxed countries in the OECD? Can the Prime Minister confirm whether these reports are true and whether the Government intends to pursue policies that will continue to ensure that Australia remains a low tax country by world standards?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —From memory, at the moment I think the Australian Federal Government tax to GDP is about 23.6 per cent. I cannot remember when it was last that low. It must have been in the 1960s, and even if we add in the revenue base of the States—
—Under Menzies, the much maligned Menzies.

—We were not doing then quite the things we are doing today—health care, education, technical and further education, the environment, sport and all sorts of areas. Even if one puts in the revenue share of the States, Australia is the second lowest tax country in the OECD—from memory, a decimal point away from the lowest which is the United States—I think sharing second lowest place with Japan on the last statistics I saw. Through the 1980s the Government has provided tax cuts so as to keep that tax to GDP share within those sorts of ranges. In fact, we have had it coming down. Revenue is down also at the moment because of the impact of the recession in years past on business in particular—particularly in relation to companies—and also because of the fact that the economy has been growing much more slowly and therefore receipts have been growing commensurately slowly and the share is down.

PARA.TAB: We will be following the policy we have been following—that is, to keep Australia a low tax country. We will not be following the policies of the Opposition which would have made it a very much higher tax country, collecting a $24 billion—net $18 billion—GST. I note that we actually had a question from the shadow Treasurer asking about tax policy on this side of the House when those opposite are walking around endorsing a policy with a $24 billion hole in it—an $18 billion net hole after the wholesale sales tax is abolished.

The Leader of the Opposition said last week, `We are reviewing all elements of Fightback apart, of course, from the GST, the life of which we terminated last week'. He terminated, of course, $18 billion net proceeds from the GST, yet still has all the funding commitments of his Fightback policy, including tax cuts, which are supposedly to be funded under its policies. He says he is sticking to Fightback, but not with the GST. So he had a $6 billion to $10 billion funding hole in his original policy. What has he got now—$6 billion to $10 billion, and add to that $18 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you going to do?

—Here they are asking a question. Who was in there arguing for the immediate abandonment of GST—the honourable member for Bennelong, the honourable member for Barker, the honourable member for Mayo, who asked a question today, the honourable member for Ryan and the honourable member for Boothby. Those in favour of retaining it were Senator Baume, the honourable member for Mackellar, Senator Short and the honourable member for La Trobe. So there is obviously a great variance of view in the Opposition about a goods and services tax. The fact of the matter is that the Opposition over there is, as usual, not looking at its policies, not looking at the big picture. What we are finding back here on the first day is that after palely loitering over there—or barely loitering, should I say—the Opposition is back on, of all things, pay television policy, yet today we find the Opposition's shadow Minister actually endorsing the policy saying, `Well we can do it for a fraction of that price'.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order under standing order 145, which deals with relevance. The Prime Minister was asked a question from his own back bench about Australia being a low taxed country in comparison with the OECD. It is not relevant in my submission for the Prime Minister now to be spending something like three minutes talking about policies of the Opposition prior to the previous election. I ask that you rule him out of order or bring him back to the question.

—Order! There is no point of order. Speakers consistently have suggested that if members of this chamber want to discuss a question of relevance, the Standing Committee on Procedure is the appropriate way to deal with it. It is in the committee's hands. To date that simply has not happened.

—Not only is there no focus on these things, but the Opposition has fallen back into bad habits. Last week the Leader of the Opposition was saying, `We risk having an exchange rate crisis'. So last week we were having an exchange rate crisis. Then he is hopping into me about constitutional change, saying that he is not going to be strung up by my hang-ups about the English-Irish issue and Jack Lang and everything else. None of this has the Opposition focusing on the broad based issues of the country, as it should be. Let me just say what was said so nicely by Phillip Adams two weekends ago in the Australian. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: The Liberal Party's phoenix is suddenly a dead budgie that, having toppled from its perch, now lies beak down in the shell grit.
All I can do is endorse those sentiments.

—I address my question to the Attorney-General. I draw his attention to the extradition treaty that Australia has signed with many countries. He will be aware that under this treaty there is no requirement for the requesting nation to provide a prima facie case and, indeed, where an uncontestable offence is debatable, the courts do not have the facilities to hear it. In the case of the Orionia several years ago which led to a massive injustice, and where an Australian citizen is involved, it could lead to a diminution of our sovereignty. Will the Attorney-General undertake to review the legislation with a view to amending the deficiency I have outlined?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The need for the Government to fulfil its election promise not to increase taxation.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —The most apposite remark that I think any of us heard in the last few weeks about the Australian economy was made by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Mr Griffiths)—part of the great new young talent of the Australian Labor Party—on the Channel 9 program yesterday morning, when he likened our economy to the Titanic and said that it would take a long time to turn around. The Titanic sank in April 1912 and there is no sign of the Titanic's being turned around. Our economy hit the iceberg of the high interest rate policy of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) back in 1989-90 and our economy is still resting on the bottom of the ocean, unmoved by the Government's rhetoric and unmoved by the wish lists that it came to the election with.

PARA.TAB: When we consider the economic statistics of the last few weeks, there is no doubt that the depth of our economy's problems, the depth to which it is stuck in the mud at the bottom of the ocean—to follow on with the metaphor of the Minister for Industry Technology and Regional Development—is very great. In the month of March we had a current account deficit blow-out of $2.1 billion. Our foreign debt is increasing day by day. There are still around one million people unemployed and the Government, including the Prime Minister, is claiming with unexpected honesty that its policies can do nothing to get those people back to work.

In the end, this is a country which is uncompetitive and we have a government which has no plan to improve that competitiveness, to get people back to work, to stabilise our debt and to reduce our current account problems. In this very damaging climate for our country, we have a government that has been re-elected, not only as a result of the scare campaign but also partly as a result of going on a spending spree trying to buy support in the community. The consequence is that it is building up—as the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis), who is at the table, knows—a more and more serious Budget deficit problem. His department has been advising him since election day, and the Treasury has been advising the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) since election day, that this is a massive problem that the Government has to address.

If there is one issue that Ministers outside the public eye have been agonising over during the last few weeks it is the size of the Budget deficit that they have created as a result of the election bribes they made. It is not surprising that even the Governor of the Reserve Bank, in an almost unprecedented manner after the election, came out and simply hammered the Government for not having an effective policy to deal with the Budget deficit.

When we look at what the Government did during the election campaign, we can see that on top of the One Nation promises, there was something like $2.6 billion worth of spending promises in the invest in the nation program between 1993-94 and 1996-97. That $2.6 billion assumes that the Government will get $1.6 billion in revenue from selling part of the Commonwealth Bank and $1.7 billion from bringing forward company tax collections. So if we strip away those one-off benefits, we are talking about a blow-out of something like $3.6 billion from Invest in the nation alone between 1993-94 and 1996-97. On 24 February, the Labor Party launched its policy and there was well over $1 billion worth of spending commitments in the same period in that policy launch.

So we get to this year's Budget and the deficit expected is something in the vicinity of $16 billion. That is about four per cent of GDP—a big blow-out from the $13.4 billion that the Government proposed in its phoney figures at the time of the Budget. When we look at the cumulative Budget deficits—and this is the critical point—that the Government has been building up between 1991-92 and in the period to 1996-97, the figures are just staggering.

The Macquarie Bank estimates that the cumulative deficit will be somewhere in the vicinity of $88,000 million. Access Economics estimates that the figure will be very similar: $83,000 million. Taking the Treasurer's best case scenario, the figure could be no lower than $65,000 million. These are Bills which will have to be paid for by future generations in this country and are Bills which, above all, have been accumulated in the cause of getting the Labor Party re-elected. If ever there was an example of fiscal recklessness, it is the policy and strategy that the Labor Party has undertaken over the last couple of years in order to try to stay in office.

The impact of this fiscal recklessness on our country will simply compound the enormous fundamental problems that we have. For example, nobody is arguing with the proposition that running an enormous Budget deficit, as the Government is, is a drain on our national savings. No-one is arguing with the proposition that running enormous Budget deficits is keeping interest rates higher than they need be and that real interest rates in this country are amongst the highest in the OECD, which of course is not conducive to ensuring that there is a recovery of investment and, therefore, employment.

But what has the Government been saying about it? At the end of last year, the Treasurer, who for some reason is absent today, put out a press release exhorting Australians to go out and spend. `Spend, spend, spend' was the cry of the Treasurer at a time when national savings were at crisis point. Then four months after the election the very same man put out a press release saying that Australians should not be spending but saving. Within four months we went from `Spend, spend, spend' to `Save, save, save'. They are not the words of a Treasurer, that is not the mind of a politician, who is set towards building confidence in this country and confidence in the way the economy is being managed.

This enormous Budget deficit is contributing to the major savings problem that Australia has. A week or so ago the ANZ bank produced a paper showing that we have the lowest level of savings in this country since 1974, that all of our investment at the moment is being financed from overseas and that we are also borrowing from foreigners in order to finance some of our current consumption.

At the end of the day, with this large number of problems that the Government has created for itself, what is it proposing to do about, above all, its gigantic Budget deficit? There are really two things that the Government has been talking about since the election. The first is its commitment to break some of its election promises. The second is the perfectly clear indication we now have both from answers in Question Time today—including the Prime Minister's dorothy dix question that he arranged through one of his advisers passing a question back to one of the backbenchers—and from leaks that have been strategically directed to different newspapers that the Government will increase a whole range of taxes. As I will explain in a minute, it will do that in a very regressive and damaging way.

Let us have a look at the broken promises. On 24 February, included in the policy speech of the Prime Minister was the promise that no age pensioner would pay tax by 1995, yet within a week of the election the Treasurer came out and said that he would renege on the promise that the Government made that by 1995 no age pensioner would pay tax. A week after the election the Treasurer explained that, in the words of the Watergate saga, that promise was `inoperative'. We had the promise during the election campaign that $100 million would be spent to buy private hospital places to try to reduce the hospital waiting list. In the last few days, Senator Richardson has explained that that promise too is likely to be `inoperative'.

We will see on the other side of the ledger an increase in a raft of different taxes. Today, at an Evatt Foundation function, the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett), one of the Government's most senior members, made some very revealing remarks when he said that Australians had to learn to understand that high levels of unemployment will be with us for a very long time—a great indictment of his own management and the management of the Labor Party. He also said that we had to accept that we would need to revive the welfare state in this country and that that would have to be funded—this is the revealing thing the honourable member for Bonython told the Evatt Foundation at lunchtime today—from increases in taxation. The honourable member for Bonython, one of the most senior members of the Government, has already let the cat out of the bag.

But so has the Minister for Finance, who is at the table. When he was asked a question today about higher taxes, we had in his answer that mealy-mouthed stuff about how the Government was not going to increase taxes—as a proportion of GDP was what he really meant. He said the overall burden of taxes was not to be increased. That does not mean we will not all end up paying taxes but that the Government will not increase taxes as a proportion of GDP.

What is the Minister really saying? What he is really saying is that the Government is going to go ahead with the tax cuts in 1994 and 1996, if it is still in government. It is perfectly clear what the Government is going to do. It is going to finance those tax cuts with a range of new, imaginative, indirect taxes and through increases in some indirect taxes that already exist.

Look at it another way. What the Government is really saying is that to help our economy it is going to spend a whole lot of extra money and—we promise, we promise—we are going to pay for it one day. The way the Government is going to pay for it is by introducing new taxes. This particular strategy, as Allan Greenspan recently pointed out to the Economic Club of New York, is a strategy that would stagnate the economy eventually and all the gains that might possibly be made through this very staggering, very slow, cyclical upturn would simply be lost. The truth is coming out day in and day out.

On the front page of the Australian newspaper today there is a leak of a speech given by the deputy secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Mr Sims. He revealed to a CEDA meeting last Wednesday that the Government indeed was considering new taxes. What is it considering? It is considering a so-called energy tax. Put green clothes on it and maybe it will not matter so much. But the energy tax constitutes a hike in petrol taxes and new taxes on electricity, gas and other forms of energy.

The Government is proposing to change the wholesale sales tax system. What does that mean? That is code for broadening the wholesale sales tax base and increasing the rates of wholesale sales tax. The Government has also decided to take a leaf out of Mr Cain's and Mr Wran's books. Remember Mr Cain and Mr Neville Wran. They used to have a practice which was called hollow logging—saying to business enterprises that they wanted higher dividends from them and sucking more money out of them. The Minister at the table is a great fan of this scheme. What the present Government is going to do is suck higher dividends out of these government business enterprises. Organisations like Telecom, Australia Post and the Federal Airports Corporation are going to compensate for that by increasing their charges. It is just another form of taxation. The really interesting thing about these new taxes is that they are hikes in indirect taxes and business costs because there is no input credit on these taxes. They are simply going to increase business costs. They are more than that. These taxes genuinely are regressive.

It is all very well to say that people are going to get income tax cuts but the people who are not going to get those tax cuts are those earning less than $20,700 a year—that is, over 40 per cent of taxpayers—and people on fixed incomes. Those people will pay the higher taxes, but there will be no compensation. That was the burden of the Government's argument against the GST. That argument was wrong. The Opposition provided compensation but the Government is increasing indirect taxes which will increase costs to business in this country, at a time when Australia is uncompetitive, and increase costs to low income Australians and pensioners and others on fixed incomes, making their lives all the more miserable than they already are.

It is no wonder that a senior Minister of this Government is using the metaphor that this country is like the Titanic. He is right. The Government's policies are not designed to turn the Titanic around because nothing will turn it around. The Government has no policies and no idea how to improve this country. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Listening to that speech, one would not think that the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) was talking about a country that is just about leading the industrialised world in terms of economic growth. No-one says that is an exceedingly rapid rate of growth, but it is certainly not an economy which is stuck in the mud, to use the term of the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mayo.

PARA.TAB: The Australian economy, like the rest of the industrialised world, has been through a recession. It is leading most of the other countries out of that recession and had a growth in 1992 of 2 1/2 per cent. That is in excess of the rate of growth for the industrialised world, which is less than two per cent—1.8 per cent on the International Monetary Fund figures. For next year, 1993, we would certainly again be ahead of the rest of the world because the IMF forecast is for the world economy to grow at about 2.2 per cent in 1993, and we will certainly do better than the 2.4 per cent that we recorded in 1992.

The economy is far from being stuck in the mud. It is an economy coming out of recession. It might not be screaming out of recession, in the way it did in the early 1980s, but neither is any other country's economy at this time. Many countries are finding it exceedingly difficult to get out of recession at all. Some, such as Germany, are still stuck in it—countries with the most dynamic post-war economies in the industrialised world. The situation must be put in some perspective. What the Opposition is saying is just ludicrous. It is still in election mode, trying to tell the people about the economy in a way that is totally out of whack with reality. The Opposition should realise that the election is over and that it can afford to be franker these days.

The shadow Treasurer also said that we have an uncompetitive economy; that we are not doing anything to improve competitiveness. Since the Government came into office, Australia's international competitiveness—and indices published by the Treasury bear out this fact—has increased by 30 per cent. We have one of the lowest inflation rates in the Western world. Productivity is increasing with the introduction of the enterprise bargaining approach to wage fixation, together with the micro-economic reforms that have been taking place at an unprecedented rate for the last several years. As a result, our competitiveness has increased very considerably.

It is therefore absurd—those opposite are away with the fairies—to suggest that we are not increasing our competitiveness. We have been doing it year after year. The Australian economy is much more competitive now. That is the major reason for the development of a high rate of growth in manufactured exports, one of the great features of the economy in recent years. If the Opposition cannot recognise that that is happening and why it is happening, then it has a terribly long way to go before it can claim to be a true alternative government.

This debate is really about the size of the Budget deficit and what is to be done about it. It is true that there has been an increase in the Budget deficit. We have moved away from the surplus of the late 1980s when, for three years, we recorded the only Budget surpluses in Australia since the introduction of the modern form of Budget accounting in the 1950s. The only Budget surpluses, therefore, have been recorded under this Government. We have moved away from those surpluses in recent years under the effect of the recession. That naturally happens because of loss of revenue and the additional expenditure that must be outlaid by the Government.

In Australia, as in every other industrialised country, the Budget situation has deteriorated. There is no doubting that that is the case. In some countries the deterioration has been infinitely more rapid than in Australia. For example, the United Kingdom had surpluses at the end of the 1980s but, as the latest International Monetary Fund figures show, it had a deficit equal to 6.2 per cent of GDP in its 1992 general government fiscal balance. The figure for Australia was 4.5 per cent, so there has been a much greater deterioration in the United Kingdom. In Italy the figure was 10.2 per cent; in Canada, 6.4 per cent; and in the United States, 4.6 per cent. Those figures represent a deficit as a proportion of GDP, and all of them are higher than Australia's.

The Opposition's argument proceeds on the basis that there is something unique happening in this country. It is saying that it is only because we have a Labor government that we are seeing a deterioration in the Budget outcome; that we have such a terrible Budget deficit solely because of the fiscal irresponsibility of the Labor Government; that if only the Government had more appropriate policies then there would be a nice Budget surplus. That is a total delusion and it is totally out of step with the reality that faces every Western industrialised country, all of which have had a deterioration in their Budget outcomes.

It is not surprising that Australia has that figure. As I said at Question Time, that is not something that we can nevertheless be relaxed about. It is not something where we can simply say, `We do not have to worry about that', even though the results of that outcome are largely unavoidable. They are not entirely unavoidable; we could have had a better Budget outcome in terms of a lesser Budget deficit if we had not put a stimulus into the economy—if we had not taken the measures that we took in the One Nation package and in the Budget to provide some stimulus to the economy to get it growing again. But, in my view, in the view of the Government and, I think, in the view of most people, that was a very appropriate policy, because it was designed to give the economy the impetus to get back onto a growth path. If we had not done that, we would have had much lower growth than we have at the present time, and more unemployment. Apparently that is what the Opposition thinks we should have. It thinks we should stick to the toughest possible Budget outcome, and in the process not care about the fact that it does not give the economy any growth, and that we have higher levels of unemployment.

That is not the Government's position. The Government, having taken that step to have responsible stimulus—as have most other countries in the Western world—recognises that that has to be taken back in the course of the next few years as the economy grows out of recession. Some of the stimulus that we have given in One Nation and the Budget will automatically come to an end because it is only there for a couple of years. So, as the economy recovers, tax revenues will pick up, budget outlays will start to decline as unemployment levels fall, and so the Budget will go through a process of some automatic repair, just as it went through a process of automatic deterioration with the recession.So we can see that in the medium-term there is going to be an improvement in the Budget outcome simply by the processes that I have just outlined.

The real question is: can we get back to a deficit of one per cent of GDP by 1996-97 simply by relying on those automatic features, or will some further steps need to be taken by the Government to ensure that that is the outcome? It is important that that is the outcome because, as I said at Question Time, this is a factor which is related to the need for a better savings effort by the nation, and that in turn is very important in ensuring that we do not have a current account problem. There is a direct relationship between the investment savings gap and the balance of payments current account gap. Unless we address that feature, then we must recognise that we are not going to address the current account, whatever else we do.

It is important. The question then is: do we need to take any further steps? As I have said previously, we recognise that we probably do need to take some other steps. The question then is: what sorts of steps do we need to take? At this stage it is not possible or appropriate for the Government to answer that. The Government will certainly be aiming to ensure that it achieves that one per cent outcome by 1996-97. In the forthcoming Budget for this year we will outline not just a Budget for 1993-94, but also a Budget scenario for the next few years to indicate the ways in which we will be likely to get to one per cent of GDP by 1996-97, and to indicate what steps we will be taking to ensure that that is the outcome.

The Opposition has already decided that that means that there are going to be big increases in taxes, and it is even telling us what those taxes will be and how unfair they will be. This is just lulu land stuff and totally absurd conjecture. The Government has no intention of introducing unfair taxes of the kind that the Opposition wanted to introduce in the form of the goods and services tax, and we have made it clear that that is definitely not part of our agenda; nor is it part of our agenda to make the tax system less fair. In the time that this Government has been in office it has been repairing the tax system to make it much fairer, tighter and less open to rorts—hopefully not open to any rorts at all these days, compared with when we came into office—and to make it much more equitable. We are not about to undo any of that in the process of putting together a fiscal policy to achieve the medium-term outcome that I have outlined.

So it is the case that this Government is facing up to the need to adopt the appropriate fiscal policy. It has taken the appropriate fiscal stance in looking at the needs of the economy in recession, and has been prepared to provide stimulus at a time when that was greatly needed. The Opposition condemned us for doing that and clearly would rather have had much more unemployment. We recognise that in the foreseeable future we have to repair that Budget outcome so that it will give us a much better savings outcome.

We have appointed the Fitzgerald committee, which is to report to the Government by the middle of this year on savings, and clearly that may have some implications for the Budget. The Treasurer indicated last September that we would be looking to take steps in that direction, to improve our savings performance, and not just in relation to public saving but also in relation to private saving. We hope that the Fitzgerald report will give us the opportunity to take further steps in that direction.

The Budget obviously will remain an important feature of the savings outcome because public dissaving, which has been a feature of the poor savings performance of the country in the last couple of years, clearly has to be addressed if we are to have a more productive savings outcome. We need to have positive savings as a nation—not to be dissaving as we have been recently—and therefore be able to rely on those savings to finance our investment rather than have to import funds with the concomitant feature of a continuing current account deficit.

It is absurd for the Opposition to condemn the Government for taking steps to introduce new taxes when the Government has made no such decision at this stage. As I said at Question Time, taxation is an issue that has to be in the ring, but that is a long way from saying that there are going to be any increases in taxes at this stage.

So this MPI is based on a number of absurdities from the Opposition—a belief that the economy is going nowhere; that it is not growing; that there is nothing being done to improve productivity or competitiveness; that nothing is being done to improve the savings performance of the nation; that nothing is being done to improve the current account outcome. They are all patently absurd. The shadow Treasurer probably, in his heart, realises this. If he does not, then he has an awful lot to learn.

TALK.START.PARA: —Listening to the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) standing in for the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and painting the rosy picture, one would think that there is nothing wrong with Australia today. Everybody knows there is. We have only got to step outside this Parliament House, or outside Canberra, and everybody will tell us that the country is in a mess, that it is performing much worse than it should be. The Government has painted itself into a position where it is going to have to break further promises and shaft its tax cuts if it is to show any sort of financial responsibility at all.

PARA.TAB: The Minister says that we are competitive. Everybody knows that the competitiveness of Australia has slipped markedly over the last few years. We only have to look at how we rate on the OECD scale. We used to be very near the top of the list on all indicators; today we are very near the bottom. On many of the indicators we are only ahead of countries such as Turkey, Finland and perhaps Greece.

As a specific example, I was talking recently to a director of a company, A.L. Vincent Industries Ltd, which makes water hydrants, washers for taps, and brass pins for brake pads. He told me they have just shifted their foundry overseas to New Zealand. The product that they previously made now comes back into Australia and is landed here, after freight, and of a comparable quality, for 30 per cent less than it could be produced in Australia. That particular company has reduced its employees to doing things like unloading the container on the wharf and distributing the product within Australia. That is a specific example, which could be mirrored a thousandfold right across Australia, of what is happening today under this Government's policies.

If we were to do an audit of the Australian economy, what would we find? We would find a country that is on its knees in many areas. Country Australia, and in particular the wool industry, is in a shocking situation, and the economy as a whole is in a mess. We have one million people unemployed whom the Minister for Finance does not even seem to be aware of. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley)—or probably more correctly the Minister for unemployment—admitted the other day that the long-term jobless numbers will just about double in the next two or three years. What a shocking situation!

The overseas debt has blown out to something approaching eightfold and is increasing at an exponential rate. The other day I worked out that if we paid off the last six months debt at the rate of $1 a second, which is not a bad rate of repayment, it would take over 300 years just to pay off that debt. This is something the Government is saddling not just us, our children and our grandchildren with, but it is saddling six, eight, 10 or 12 generations hence. We are supposed to be having an economic recovery in this country. Every indicator which has come out lately shows me that it is faltering. The current account deficit for March was $2.1 billion, which is—

TALK.START.PARA: —Devastating!

—It is devastating indeed. Exports were down seven per cent; imports were up 16 per cent, and the imports flooding into this country today are at a record level. Not since January 1990 have we had a figure of this magnitude. When we cast our minds back to those sorts of figures, we remember that is the reason the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the Treasurer as he then was, put us into the recession that we had to have. We have gone through all this pain and we are virtually back where we started. Goodness knows what the Government now has in store for us.

PARA.TAB: As the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), said, our savings policy is absolutely shot. Savings in this country are at their lowest level since 1974. I do not have to remind honourable members who was in power then. Last year's December quarter figures showed that savings had fallen by another $850 million, which was the seventh successive fall in a row. They had fallen on only one other occasion in the last 20 years, and that was over two quarters in the 1982-83 recession. Now we have had seven successive falls. It is an unbelievable position. We have unprecedented levels of borrowing from overseas, not just for investment but, more alarmingly, also for consumption. In a sense, we are selling off Australia's interests to overseas interests for the simple reason that we are spending more than we are producing and we are spending more than we are earning.

It comes back to the old adage: the Labor Party cannot handle money. We have seen it in Western Australia, we have seen it in Victoria and we are seeing it today in South Australia. The only reason Queensland is doing half decently is because it inherited government from the National Party and nothing has been done since. We are seeing it all over Australia today and I believe those figures I have just trotted out are convincing evidence.

In a sense, the policies that the Government is pursuing are anti-Australian policies. I think that is pretty ironic in view of the current agenda that the Prime Minister is running. Everybody knows what the solutions should be: industrial relations reform which overseas countries are putting in place, but which the present Prime Minister has no stomach for; micro reform which is needed urgently and at a pace which is faster than glacial; reform on the waterfront which should be occurring but is not; and also cuts in spending in non-productive areas. But this Prime Minister's solutions involve pretending that this Government is doing the above things and pretending it is making industrial relations reforms, although he virtually read out the coalition's policy, but then tacked on at the end—after a few phone calls from Bill Kelty—that the unions must be involved, which almost ensures that it will stall again.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happens if you don't belong to a union?

PARA.TAB: For heaven's sake, a year or so ago it was the flag; the Prime Minister was going to change the flag. That got the economy off the front page. TALK.START.PARA: —I think that what we have just witnessed this afternoon is one of those incompetent fishing expeditions that the Opposition demonstrated its great skill at in the last Parliament. It kicked off in the 37th Parliament with the same degree of skill. We know we are in for a serious economic debate in this place when the Opposition trots out the National Party to run as its second speaker. We know we are in for a serious, in-depth discussion about the issues confronting the national economy when the National Party is up there as the second string speakers—and second string they are.

PARA.TAB: Central to the issue before the Parliament at present is the question of how much the Government spends, how much of the national resources we are consuming in Government, how much of the money that we are collecting we are spending, and whether or not we are spending too much. Let us look at Government expenditure as it now stands, as well as the central government deficit. As the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) has already mentioned, the 1992-93 Budget sets out a central Government deficit of 3.3 per cent. The December 1992 OECD Economic Outlook records a central government deficit in the United States of 5.8 per cent, which is substantially higher than in Australia. The United Kingdom, adopting the sorts of policies which those opposite are still espousing, has a central government deficit of 6.3 per cent. Italy has a central government deficit of 10.6 per cent and Canada has a central government deficit of 3.4 per cent.

The fact of life in OECD countries is that private sector investment has gone down and sensible, responsible government action has been taken in all of them to generate increased economic activity. At the same time we must recognise that revenues of all those governments, including Australia's, have fallen. The facts of life are that our 3.3 per cent deficit in this financial year is well below the OECD average, lower than any of the G7 countries. It is a very modest stimulus to the economy, but one which those opposite would not have delivered.

In the election just past those opposite went to the people of Australia promising not to increase economic activity but to choke it—to withdraw funds from the economy and to top that off with an inequitable tax—which the people of Australia have resoundingly rejected. If we look not just at the present but at the past, it is interesting to note what the philosophies of those opposite in practice have delivered to the people of Australia. Since the current methods of accounts were kept in our Budget documents from 1951 to the current time we have had 42 Budgets. Those opposite have delivered 29 of those 42 Budgets. I ask the question of those opposite: out of the 29 Budgets that they delivered whilst they were in government through that period, how many balanced Budgets or surplus Budgets did they deliver? The answer is zero, nil.

Not since Bob Menzies got the thought of forming the Liberal Party have those opposite delivered one surplus Budget. In fact, the record shows quite clearly that the only surplus Budgets that stand on the record since the current methods of account have been kept were the Budgets from 1987-88 to 1990-91, delivered by this Labor Government, by the then Treasurer, now Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

They are the stark facts of life that the record shows and which those opposite would do well to learn by. Their performance today demonstrates that they have learnt very little from it. In those four Budgets in which we recorded a surplus, we amassed a surplus of some $18 billion; that is $18 billion effectively saved in the Commonwealth coffers which, coincidentally, is about the same amount as those opposite overspent during their last period in office.

One of the other yardsticks that is important in this debate about how much money we should get through taxes and how much we should spend is how much of the total cake, how much of the Australian domestic product, do the Government outlays consume? This year the Budget provides for government outlays of about 27 per cent of GDP. Let us measure that against past occasions. In 1982-83, the last Budget that those opposite delivered, government outlays as a percentage of GDP were higher, at 28.8 per cent. The record shows quite clearly that this Government has ensured a modest slice of the gross domestic product going to the public sector.

Indeed, there is good argument in a whole range of policy areas why government outlays might be increased. But the facts of life are, and the record shows, that this Government has been about reducing the size of the economy consumed by the public sector, in spite of the protestations of those opposite mentioned earlier in this debate.

One thing that has contributed to that reduction has also been the fact that Australia now ranks as the third or second lowest taxed country in the OECD. Putting those things together we find a Labor government record in which government outlays as a percentage of GDP have shrunk since we came to office, not grown; a tax regime which has seen Australian tax now at the third lowest rate in the OECD; and a central government deficit lower than the OECD average and well below those of our trading partners with whom we like to compare ourselves.

Those are areas of the economy in which the Budget is directly involved. But, of course, in all of these things the critical factor at the end of the day is what is happening out there in the wider economy. The most important yardstick of that is what is happening with growth in our domestic product. Again, the record demonstrates the positive performance of this Government.

The December 1992 OECD Economic Outlook records economic growth in real terms in GDP in Australia at two per cent for the calendar year 1992. That compares more than favourably with the OECD countries and is better than any of the G7. The United States, by comparison, is projected to grow at 1.8 per cent; Japan at 1.8 per cent; Germany at 1.4 per cent; France at 1.9 per cent; Italy at 1.2 per cent; and Canada at 1.3 per cent.

The United Kingdom, adhering to the sorts of fundamentalist right-wing conservative policy espoused by the Opposition in Fightback, is projected not to grow at all this financial year but to remain in recession to the tune of minus one per cent. That is the OECD's December forecast for the last calendar year.

So the sorts of prescriptions that the Opposition put to the people of Australia, and that were rejected by the people of Australia, have seen the United Kingdom stay in recession longer than any of the other OECD countries with which it would want to compare itself. The United Kingdom still finds itself running at a negative growth of one per cent.

Since we have been in Government we have seen this nation's economy grow substantially. Today our gross domestic product is some 25 per cent larger than it was when we came into office. At the same time we have not only made more, but we have also increased the percentage of that product which is being exported. In 1983-84 we were exporting about 14 or 15 per cent of what we made. In 1991-92 that had grown to just under 18 per cent.

So we are making more as a nation and we are turning more of that into revenue for the nation by selling it to the rest of the world. All of that has happened at the same time as the Government's slice of gross domestic product has fallen; at the same time as we have reduced the tax burden across the board; and at the same time as we have seen the tax revenue or the tax base broadened so that the responsibility is shared more evenly—none of which the Opposition was able to do in office and none of which it was able to come up with as alternative policies when it went before the people.

Today we have seen the fishing expedition in the lead-up to the Budget session, and those honourable members opposite have given a pretty woeful performance in trying to get anything useful out of it. They will need to do better if this place and the public outside are going to take them any more seriously in the 37th Parliament than they did in the 36th Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not agree to this motion for a number of very substantial reasons. The first and most important reason why the Opposition will not agree to this motion is that it demonstrates yet again the utter contempt of the Labor Party for the proper processes of the Parliament of this country. On this occasion the Government will not be able to drag out some example of this sort of thing having been done when we were in government.

PARA.TAB: This is the third occasion since Federation—the third occasion in 93 years—that a guillotine has been used in the first two weeks of a sitting of the new Parliament. On the two other occasions that the guillotine was used in such indecent haste, it was used under a Labor government. It was first used on 10 July 1974—I remember it well, it was my first Parliament—when we had the joint sitting of the 29th Parliament. It was used for the second time, almost 16 years later, on 15 May 1990.

Now, in the first two weeks, long before honourable members have completed their maiden speeches, the Government is moving a guillotine. What is the excuse that the Government gives? The excuse is that there has been a natural build-up of Bills and the Government has to get itself organised as a new government. Does the Government expect us to break down and howl about the fact that it has to reorganise itself? After the way the Government has been buffooning around over pay television, it is a long way short of getting itself organised as a new government.

But the real objection that the Opposition has to what the Government is doing on this occasion is that it really demonstrates again that, when it comes to any sort of respect for the institution of Parliament, this Government could not give a damn. One of the courtesies that this Parliament is meant to extend is the opportunity for new members on both sides of the Parliament to have a decent Address-in-Reply debate so that they can get their maiden speeches out of the way not long after they have come into the Parliament.

By moving this motion now, the Government is aborting the opportunity that many new members have, certainly on our side of the House, to conduct their maiden speeches on the Address-in-Reply. What kind of courtesy is that to new members? None at all. The Government does not care about new members. As far as it is concerned—whether they are on the Government's side of the Parliament or whether they are on our side—they are division-fodder.

I think it is nothing short of disgraceful—and it shows a quite contemptuous attitude of this Government towards the processes of this Parliament—that it should bring on a guillotine. It used to be the view that the use of the guillotine was avoided unless the Government got into a desperate position at the end of a parliamentary session. Now we are invited to support a guillotine on the basis that the Government is in a desperate position at the beginning of a parliamentary sitting. If ever a government ought not to be in a desperate position, it is at the beginning of a Parliament, just after it has been returned at an election with three years of government ahead of it. The Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) comes along to us and says, `Please, will you support this motion because we need to have a guillotine so that we can get all of this legislation through'.

I would say to the Leader of the House: if the Government wants to get this legislation through, it should let the Parliament sit longer. We do not mind. We are perfectly happy to sit through June; we are perfectly happy to sit into July. As far as I am concerned, the more this Parliament sits, the better and, as far as the Australian people are concerned, the more the Parliament sits, the better.

Do honourable members know that, between 1 January this year and the time the Budget is brought down in the third week of August, the House of Representatives will have sat the princely number of 10 days only—10 days in a period of something like nine or 10 months. That is supposed to be representative democracy!

Of course, the blokes opposite are all about whittling away the prerogatives of other than the executive power of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). This Government is all about diminishing the power of parliament and, in the long term, about diminishing the role of the States in the Senate in the political set-up of this country. As any discerning Australian knows, the Government's real republican agenda is not limited to some stroke of a pen change in the head of state; it also has an end product.

Then there is good old Titanic on the other side of the House, who is not in the chamber at the moment. One can always rely on the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Mr Griffiths) to let the cat out of the bag. He will be the John Button of the Keating Ministry. He will be the bloke who will blab it out and he will get more invitations from Laurie Oakes than any other member of the Keating Ministry. Laurie Oakes will have him on television every Sunday saying, `Alan, what do you think of the balance of payments? What do you think of the role of the States?'. Yesterday Laurie Oakes asked him about the States and he said, `Oh, well. That is not an urgent priority at present'. That is a terrific reassurance to people who are concerned about the federal set-up of this country. All that one of the Prime Minister's closest colleagues can say is, `Oh, well. It is not an urgent priority at present'.

The fact is that this tawdry little exercise today by the Leader of the House, a motion moved in his normal, nonchalant, calm, `how could I possibly be deceiving you' manner, is just—if I can pursue an analogy that we rather like at the moment—the tip of the iceberg as far as the attitude of this Government and members on that side of the House is concerned towards the role of the Parliament.

In the 93 years since the Commonwealth of Australia was established there have been only three occasions—and this is the third—on which a guillotine has been moved in the first two weeks of a parliamentary sitting.

PARA.TAB: As the re-elected Government, those opposite are entitled to feel politically smug. But they are not entitled, as a re-elected government, to run roughshod over the body that is supposed to be the clearing house of the nation's political ideas. That is not my expression; that is the Prime Minister's expression. But, if he really believes that this is the clearing house of the ideas of the nation, that this is where it all happens and where it all matters, and that when people come together here they are really interested in debating issues that affect Australians, why on earth is the Government denying the representatives of the Australian people—in the midst of the worst crisis the wool industry has suffered perhaps in its existence, and certainly since the end of World War II—an opportunity of seriously debating that issue?

The Government has no answer to that. The only reason it is doing what it is now doing is that when it comes to the crunch it does not care about parliament. As far as this Government is concerned, parliament is a necessary evil and is something it has to put up with. The Government sits for the shortest possible time and the only thing it is interested in is Question Time because Question Time is loaded in favour of the Government and dominated by the Government. The Government is demonstrating its utter contempt for the parliamentary system by introducing a guillotine within the first two weeks of this Parliament's sitting.

If this were the eve of Christmas, we had been sitting month after month, and we had had plenty of time to debate all the important issues and the Leader of the House came in and said, `Look, John, you really have to agree to this because we won't be able to go home for Christmas', there might be some sense in it. Politically speaking, the Government has the ball at its feet because it has just won an election. Yet what does it do? It makes the Parliament sit for a contemptuously short period of two weeks, puts up a guillotine motion like this one, tells the representatives of the woolgrowers of Australia they cannot have a decent debate on the future of their industry and expects us to believe that it takes the Parliament seriously. This completes a trifecta of contempt for the institution of parliament as far as the Labor Party is concerned.

I conclude by reminding the House again that in the 93 years of Federation, on only three occasions—and this is the third—have governments moved guillotine motions in the first two weeks of a parliamentary sitting, and all of those have been moved by Labor governments. Of course, this is the second time in a row. The motion was moved in May 1990 at the convening of the 36th Parliament and it was moved on this occasion at the convening of the 37th Parliament. The Opposition will oppose the motion because it represents an expression of the Government's contempt for the role of parliament in the constitutional processes of this country.
