I look at the Australian Capital Territory Bill on road transport charges. I have an understanding of what the legislation means. It is mirror legislation for the other States. The Minister's own colleagues in Western Australia did not want it and I do not think my colleagues in Western Australia want it, yet for some unknown reason we have to get it through by 30 June for the Australian Capital Territory—a frantic situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —And New South Wales, and Victoria, and Queensland; it is like most of the stuff introduced.

—This is the only time I have had my say. The same applies to the honourable member who is interjecting. Because of the guillotine, the only comment of his that will be on the record is what he just said, whatever that happened to be. That is two of us. In fact, the same can be said of the 147 of us.

PARA.TAB: What I am saying is that this legislation is still very contentious throughout Australia, that not everybody agrees on it and that the New South Wales Government is not really sure how it is going to apply. But there is going to be no discussion on it in this place. The members from New South Wales can say nothing; the members from Western Australia can say nothing because it will be guillotined and we will be lucky to have time for the shadow Minister's response.It is a piece of watershed legislation, and that is the sort of contempt that the Government shows. It comes back to a few famous statements like `Question Time is a courtesy handed to the Parliament by the Executive'. It is like the contempt that was shown to Speaker Cope.

All of these matters are significant and contiguous with what we are on about today, further and further lowering the reputation of this place, and in the process elevating the position of the Senate. If honourable members opposite think that is a good idea, they are going to be given the opportunity to vote on it in a minute. We know how that vote is going to come out. A large number of people will vote for it—80, I think the Minister reminded us the other day. He believes that justice resides in the numbers. But with 80 people voting for it, that means that there are 80 people that do not give a damn for this place as an institution. They are going to vote it down just like a few people previously voted down Speaker Cope. I remind the Minister that his father was not one of them because his father at least had some respect for this institution. He would not come in here and do such an outrageous thing. He came in and participated in the next vote, and that is evidence he was in the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can you talk about this in this place?

—I am talking about the honourable member's contempt of this place, and he is going to demonstrate it very shortly in a division. I will sit on this side in defence of this place because I believe it is the premier chamber and I regret sincerely the way that the backbencher newly arrived is going to become vote fodder and not concern himself one scrap with his responsibilities that people gave him just a few weeks ago. They voted for him because they thought he was going to represent them. They really and truly thought he was going to do something for them. Does he know what any of this stuff is about? Has he got a view on it? Is he worried about the circumstances of the people in his electorate, as they might be affected by this? No. He will not be talking on any of it. He will put his hand up when the Government tells him. It will be a long time before he asks a question about the people who put their faith in him. He will get little bits of paper, but let me remind him that when he gets a question from a Minister, and his instructions from the Whip to ask it, he should make a point of reading it. There are a number of very embarrassed members in this place who have actually asked questions that were out of order, written by Ministers' officers—quite a frequent occurrence. So I just give him a little bit of advice while he is new around the place: he should just read the questions put under his nose.
—He has already learned to reject your drives.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The Parliamentary Secretary will cease interjecting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Anyhow, government members are all going to demonstrate it. I will send a copy out to his electorate so they know they have elected a dud, somebody who has no intention whatsoever of worrying about what the people in his electorate might think about this legislation. The Leader of the House says, `Guillotine it through, I will back you up; and if it compounds upon my people, too bad. The Labor Party is still in government'. That is the problem, and he has just demonstrated how he is going to go. We know him from here on in. He has another totally silent mate up there. I will give him the benefit of the doubt. By his silence, I think he might join the club. I will bet he does not cross the floor. It will be interesting to see where the Independents come out on this. The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Mack) will probably vote with us; he usually votes with us on any procedural matter. He only votes with the Government on matters of importance.

PARA.TAB: I take great pleasure in supporting the honourable member for Bennelong on this issue because it is an outrageous insult to this place. It is not necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the views of the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) that this House should not agree with the motion put by the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) to guillotine debate. If honourable members ever wanted a better example of the hypocrisy of this Government, which has become a hallmark of this Government in its 10 years in office, they only have to sit here and remember the words that this Government touted throughout the electorate during the weeks of the campaign when it went out and said to the people of Australia, `Vote for us because we listen to what you say. Vote for us because we do not divide the nation. Vote for us because we do not push through change at a rapid rate without considering your views'.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members will recall the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and other members of the Government, who were urging the population to vote against the coalition because we stood for rapid change and we did not listen to the views of the people. As a consequence, they were told they should reject the Opposition. All that was just empty words. Here today is the living proof of the hypocrisy of this Government, and these people who sit here smiling so congenially opposite me today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Gee, that's generous.

—It is generous of me to say they do smile. Do honourable members know the reason why they are smiling? Do honourable members know the reason why these people do not want to come back next week? There is a solution to all this, and it has been put by the two previous speakers. If we have so much important legislation that has to be put through by the end of June we can come back next week. The reason why they are all smiling, the reason why they are not going to come back next week, is that they are going to clear off overseas. I will bet the new Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr O'Keefe), has a you-beaut, little, round the world jaunt starting next Monday at taxpayers' expense, highlighting his importance as he visits other parliamentary secretaries to discuss the inner workings of ping-pong balls or something like that.

PARA.TAB: Mr Beazley interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I will bet the Leader of the House will be off too. I will bet he will be heading off overseas. The reason why we have to have this guillotine debate today is that government members do not want to come back next week. A very sensible solution to the problem that the Government has highlighted to us this afternoon has been put forward by the honourable member for Bennelong. Let us come back next week. The reason we are not coming back is that these blokes are on the gravy train, and they are drooling at the thought of getting on it.

PARA.TAB: I was interested to read of the goings on in Caucus last Wednesday night. When a Labor Party member does not become a Minister or a Parliamentary Secretary, he should not despair, because the prizes do not end with being a Minister of the Crown. The prizes start with being a Minister. Second prize is being a Parliamentary Secretary. The third prize is being the Government Whip. The other prizes of course are being the committee chairmen. Do we not have a lot of committee chairmen over there with their snouts right in the trough. I see the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis). Honourable members on this side of the House know he is a keen international traveller, but what we did not realise was that as Chairman of the Public Works Committee he picked up an extra 11 1/2 grand prize for winning that. I think he has got the safest Labor seat in New South Wales. We know the reason why these fellows are putting this legislation through today is that they are all off on these gravy trains around the world at the taxpayers' expense. That is why they are not prepared to debate the serious issues.

I am reminded of just how often this Government ducks when the going gets tough. I was just reading a speech a few minutes ago about how this Government introduced the guillotine on the Australia card debate. Remember the debate on the Australia Card back in 1989. The Australia card was highly controversial and was opposed by a broad section of our society. The Bill was introduced by this Government. What did the Government do when the Bill was before the House? We did not debate it as one would expect a matter as important as that would be debated. We had a guillotine. I think the total debate allowed for the Australia Card in this House was an hour and a half. Government members were not prepared to face up to the views of other people in our society who were opposed to the Australia Card. Thank God there were enough people in Australia who stood up, and we saw that Bill disappear. It is this type of thing that we are seeing today.

The Government is on the back foot in the first week of the Parliament. When the Government should be basking in the glory of its successful election campaign—it has come back after a win, and good luck to it—when the first week or two should be its crowning glory, it is on the back foot. Why? Because the Government has made a complete mess of the pay TV issue—an issue involving the investment of billions of dollars and affecting the future of communications in Australia into the next century and beyond. What is the Government doing about it? There is to be a little debate on the issue in the legislation that is to be guillotined—guillotined because the Government does not want to listen to the Opposition highlighting the inadequacies in the legislation. That is why the legislation is being whipped through at maximum pace.

My well-known colleague the honourable member for Bennelong, who spoke before me, referred to the Road Transport Charges Bill, an item of legislation which falls within my shadow portfolio. I have looked at the legislation and, interestingly enough, it is a Bill which only applies to the ACT. There is no urgency in introducing the legislation because it does not need to be enacted until about the middle of next year when other States enact similar legislation. There is no reason for the Bill to be enacted in a hurry. Likewise, the substance of the Dairy Produce Amendment Bill 1993, the last item on the list provided by the Leader of the House, is a very minor amendment which would allow the Dairy Board to borrow money and make hedging arrangements so that it can act in line with other statutory authorities under the Government's wing. If the board has lived without those rights for the last few years, it can live without them for a few more months. There is no urgency attached to that particular legislation.

Some of the legislation before us does not need to be enacted quickly. I would urge honourable members on both sides of the House to take into account that this is the people's House; this is the place where democracy is supposed to work. I am glad that honourable members on the other side of the House agree with me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—Anyone who says `Hear, hear!' must stand up for the principle of democracy which allows for views other than those of the Government to be properly heard. Anyone who stands up for that principle is representing the people who have put them in this place. Anyone who does not stand up for the right of honourable members on both sides to have their say and to express the views of their constituents will vote for this motion.

PARA.TAB: I ask honourable members on both sides of the House to take heed of the suggestion made by the honourable member for Bennelong to come back here next week—to cancel the overseas trips—and give the Bills the airing they deserve. I ask them not to support the guillotine this afternoon and to give democracy free rein in this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate having the opportunity to make a few—
—I am glad there is no pressure on the time!

—As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications observes, we might all be punished by the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) for taking up time now. I am cognisant of that fact, and I will be brief, but I could not let the opportunity to speak pass. I have entered into debates in this House on many occasions and with considerable enthusiasm.
—Riveting!

—That might be overstating it, but I have certainly been enthusiastic. When I was elected to this House I thought that debate was an important part of the job. It has only taken me three years to learn that in many ways this place is treated as a joke. The joking and laughing that are going on over on the other side of the House makes that fact very clear.

PARA.TAB: This is a very serious matter indeed. I do not want to come back here next week, but I take the view that I have been elected to come here to do a job which entails giving proper consideration to matters put before us. A large number of matters have been put before us today which are to be subjected to the guillotine. I do not know whether any one matter is ultimately more important than another. I personally take a great deal of interest in matters concerning veterans affairs, and that is one matter that is listed. What concerns me is that when the guillotine has been applied on previous occasions there have been consequential delays in enacting the legislation. To think that decisions can be made and votes taken without any debate at all is absolutely disgraceful, and that has happened on occasions. It has also often occurred that proper consideration has not been given to matters and we have had to come back at another time to correct the problem that we have created. There are numerous examples that I can cite of such unintended consequences.

If the Leader of the House gets the chance, I would like him to justify what is going on here. I feel that the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis) takes this place seriously, and I respect him for that. Perhaps he will not acquiesce to this sort of activity. He has said on more than one occasion that we should be able to debate things properly. This House of the Parliament is what represents democracy to the people of Australia. Perhaps the people do not know what I have learnt over the past three years: that the proceedings of this House are a farce. I object to that. I am paid to come here to do a job. The guillotining of these Bills precludes me from carrying out my responsibilities. The people of Australia should be aware that it is the Government that has created that situation.

As I have said, for the people watching and listening to the proceedings of this House, this House represents democracy. I say to them that it does not. What we are witnessing today shows that the Government treats democracy with contempt and treats it as a farce. I ask the Leader of the House to give a reason—a reason that we can take back to our constituents—that explains why the Government is preventing us from properly doing the jobs we are elected to do and, perhaps more importantly, paid to do. If I am not here to debate and take part in the process properly, what am I here to do? Will the Leader of the House answer that question for me? I do not ask that question facetiously. I seriously challenge the Leader of the House to answer it.

Ultimately, we could dispense with the proceedings in this place, and perhaps that is what the Government intends. We could sit outside and the Government could go on its merry way. It might yet come to the point where, by way of protest, I will stay away. Why should I participate in such a farce? Why should I acquiesce to the contempt in which the Government holds this process?

As I said, I do not want to come back next week. While I am not going overseas, there are other things to which I could attend. However, because I am paid to do a job I would happily come back next week to do the job properly. I am prepared to do that, as are all honourable members on this side of the House. Why is the Government not prepared to do so? I ask the honourable member for Brisbane, because we often participate in debates, how he views this process. How does he justify this process? The Government shows by what it is doing today—as the honourable member for Bennelong and the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) have both said—that it has contempt for the process. But it goes beyond that: it shows how little consideration the Government has for propriety, for convention or for tradition. It wants to change everything. It is no wonder that the people of Australia are concerned about the Government's agenda. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) would like to be not only president but also dictator. The people of Australia should be very concerned about anything he proposes. Those opposite should tell me why we cannot debate important matters—whether it concerns veterans affairs or wool—otherwise, they should change their minds and do the decent thing by the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to contribute to this debate because I believe that as a member of parliament duly elected by a constituency in this country there is no issue more important than the regard we have for the operations of the Australian Parliament. To use the words that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) used in Question Time last week, the Australian Parliament is ultimately the clearing house of the nation. People from diverse backgrounds and different interests put issues before the House and expect decisions, and look to the proper government of this country.

PARA.TAB: I suspect there would not be one Australian who would disagree with the proposition that in the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament any duly elected member, who represents 70,000 or 80,000 people in his or her electorate, has the responsibility and the right to speak on any matter that comes before this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you doing now?

—I ask the honourable member for McEwen to be quiet for a moment. The Government has advanced a proposition to deny members, including the honourable member for McEwen, the right to speak on these matters. We have a proposition to deny members of this Parliament the right—indeed I would say the responsibility—to speak on behalf of the people who put them in this place. If the people in this gallery here today, or members of the Australian public were asked if they believe that members should have the right and the responsibility to speak on their behalf in this place, and to bring their industry and judgment to propositions before the major Parliament in this country, I suspect that there would be a resounding yes over the length and breadth of this nation.

PARA.TAB: In recent years we have heard that this place has become a house of ill-repute; that the Parliament of Australia has fallen in the estimation of the Australian people to such an extent that they regard the procedures and the operations of the Parliament as a joke. If this place has fallen in the estimation of the members—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. In the context of the normal use of the term `a house of ill-repute', I wonder whether the honourable member for Menzies does in fact mean that in reference to this chamber.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suspect that if we asked ordinary Australians they would say that the reputation of this place has fallen considerably in recent years. The honourable member well knows that; he has talked about it himself. He is aware that the reputation of this place has been lowered in the minds of ordinary Australians, and their disgust at the practices of this place therefore reflects on all of us.

PARA.TAB: In any ordinary year we sit in this House for about 18 weeks out of 52. This year we will sit for about 12 weeks. In the second week of a new Parliament we have a proposition from the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) that we should guillotine debate on a whole series of legislation which the Government considers to be important enough to bring here. We are talking about this place operating for about 12 weeks out of 52 this year. We are told that there is such urgency that we have to use the guillotine and that we cannot sit for an extra week. Ordinarily this Parliament sits in June. Why are we not sitting in June?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is too cold.

—The honourable member for Watson says that it is too cold. It may be in his electorate. The Parliament often sits in June. Since I have been here the Parliament has been sitting in June. Why can we not sit in June again?
—It sat in July years ago.

—As the honourable member for Bennelong adds, in the past it has also sat in July. Apart from the wisecracks from members on the other side, there is deafening silence to the proposition that the Parliament ought to sit for a sufficient length of time to debate the legislation that the newly elected Government of the day believes important enough to put before the House of Representatives.

PARA.TAB: In recent days and weeks we have heard a lot about raising debate about fundamental institutions in Australia; about the way in which Australia is governed; about who should be the head of State and what powers that head of State should operate under; and about what should be the relationship between the Federal Parliament and the States, and between the States themselves. These matters were raised by the Prime Minister, and we are talking about questions that relate to the institutions of society. Yet at the same time the Government is showing such respect for this institution that it wants to cut off debate in the second week of a new Parliament and shove through legislation without permitting it to be debated entirely.

I am not surprised at the silence from members on the other side. They have the opportunity to stand up in this debate like anybody else and put forward their beliefs about the way in which the Parliament should operate. I would be highly surprised if any of them do. It is okay to make wisecracks, but when we come to the fundamental proposition about how this Parliament should operate, there is a deafening silence. I suspect the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham) secretly adheres to the proposition that each member of parliament has a responsibility on behalf of the people who put him or her here to stand up and debate any piece of legislation that is introduced into this Parliament. It is a great pity that the Government has decided not to adopt that proposition in which so many Australians believe.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to join in expressing dismay that the Government is once again using these guillotine procedures, and doing so in the very first days of this Parliament. Over the years we have become used to the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) coming into this chamber towards the end of each session and announcing that, because of the great pressure of Government business and the enormity of the Government program, it will be necessary to limit debate on Bills. In the life of the last Parliament over half the Bills were subject to a limitation of debate. Over half of all the legislation that came into this place could not be discussed adequately. It was therefore inevitable that much of it would be recirculated; it would come back into this chamber when the obvious defects in it were discovered in the other place, or through a brief passage of implementation of that legislation.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the House always demonstrates how sad he is that the guillotine is occurring, but that it is tragically inevitable. None of his excuses will hold good this time. Here we are after only three sitting days, but two working days of this Parliament, and we are told that 30 Bills must be guillotined. When the Leader of the House introduced the motion, he spoke about the list being smaller than on some previous occasions. It is true that there have been longer lists, but the reality is that in this instance this list of 30 Bills represents virtually 100 per cent of the real legislation coming before the Parliament. All of it will be subject to the guillotine. There will be not one piece of legislation before the Budget session on which all members who wish to speak will have the opportunity to do so. In every instance there will be a curtailment of the debate.

There were some new members here a few moments ago, and even they have deserted the chamber. They are obviously embarrassed that they are being asked to support their Government. Almost the first division that they participate in is one to curtail democracy, to curtail the opportunity for the Opposition to speak. What those new members need to remember is that, whilst every opportunity will be provided and every courtesy will be given to them to make their maiden speeches in these early days, next time round they will be amongst the people who will be denied the opportunity to speak. They will be amongst the people who will not have an opportunity to put the views of their electorate on a particular issue. No matter how important a matter may be to their constituency, the guillotine will be used to prevent them from exercising what they would have regarded as their right, as a member of parliament, to contribute to the debate.

What we have is a Parliament that is scheduled to sit for only nine days in eight months between before Christmas last year and the bringing down of the Budget in the third week of August. What an abysmal record. I can remember years ago some people being critical of the Queensland coalition Government for not sitting very often, but if it had ever dared to sit for only nine days in eight months there would have been riots in the street. But nine days is what this Government considers to be adequate. One of those days, of course, was a ceremonial day taken up by the processes of the opening of the Parliament, so in fact we will have eight days of actual debating time in eight months. So it has been decided that 30 Bills will now be guillotined through by the end of this week. That is really an unsatisfactory state of affairs.

A lot of people have referred to hidden agendas, the real reasons why the Parliament is sitting for only eight days when there are probably something like 50 or 60 potential days available. Some people have referred to the need for government members to undertake overseas trips. The other obvious reason why the Government is anxious to shorten the number of sitting days is to reduce the number of Question Times. They hope that maybe the Minister for Communications (Mr Beddall) can survive three or four Question Times but know there is no way he will ever survive a dozen or 20.

I was interested to read the comments of the Minister for Communications in the Sunday Mail that he had in fact erred by providing too much information during Question Time. I would like to know what titbit amongst the paucity of information he supplied was greater than the public had a right to know. Indeed, there is a real denial of opportunity for Ministers to be put under scrutiny, particularly those Ministers who have demonstrated over a long period of time that they have not got a grasp of the issues in their portfolio, and this provides them with a further opportunity to run away from the sort of scrutiny that they really ought to be subject to.

I come back to the guillotine motion. It is quite clear that this one does not come as a result of pressure of government business or any inability to adequately deal with a comprehensive program. Two debating days after the commencement of the Parliament we are being asked to agree to a guillotine. We can come to only one conclusion: that the Government's management of its legislative program is not accidental or something that is beyond the capacity of the Government. It has not been forced into a guillotine position. It is clearly a deliberate program to curtail debate. It cannot be regarded in any other way. It is a deliberate action to ensure that the legislation proposed is not subject to scrutiny, that the Opposition is denied the opportunity to raise issues, and that members of Parliament are denied the opportunity to put before this place matters of significance to their electorate.

I make an appeal particularly to the new members of the Government. Let them take an opportunity early in their career to demonstrate their commitment to democracy—particularly the member for Lilley (Mr Swan), who is steeped in the party processes. Let him demonstrate that he is not down here just to put his hand up when the factional leader says that that is what he is required to do, that he does really believe that Australia ought to be a better place in which to live, that he wants to make a contribution to making this country a better place and that he wants an opportunity to contribute to the debate. He will only get that opportunity if he is prepared to stand up early in his career and demonstrate to the Leader of the House and to the Government that he stands for democracy, that he believes in freedom of speech, and that he believes that this chamber should be used for its intended purpose—to thoroughly scrutinise legislation and to ensure that matters that are passed and become the law of the land, are indeed in the national interest and are likely to achieve good things for the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland), who I see now is walking back to his side of the chamber, I am very pleased to be returned here after an involuntary absence of a number of years. Like the honourable member for McEwen, I am well aware of how low this Parliament is held in public esteem. I am aware of how the people of Australia feel robbed and cheated by the fact that the 147 parliamentary representatives elected just a month or so ago, on 13 March, are not able to come in here and talk about the important items of legislation which have been listed for debate.

PARA.TAB: When I was out of Parliament I was absolutely outraged, like many of the people of Australia, over the shambles into which the last Parliament descended. I actually thought, during the first couple of Question Times last week, that the Government might have been serious about reform. But when we saw the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) chopping off Question Time eight or 10 minutes early just a day or two into the session to protect a weak Minister, the honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall)—a Minister on the ropes, a Minister who is indeed for the political high jump, we knew that leopards do not change their spots. I am also pleased to see the honourable member for Lilley (Mr Swan) here in the chamber. He has not made his maiden speech yet so he cannot, according to tradition, interject—

TALK.START.PARA: —It wouldn't worry him.

—It would not worry them; it normally does not worry them. The honourable member for Lilley has been remarkably silent over the last three or four days since the Parliament resumed. In the media in Queensland he never shuts up on the importance of honesty and accountability in government. I must say I share his sentiments in support of honesty and accountability. But now that he has come down here, why does he not bring some of his undoubted machine muscle, some of his undoubted political prowess, through the factional arrangements to bring pressure to bear on his factional colleague the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley).

PARA.TAB: I think that the people of Australia do deserve better. The ivory tower that this place has become under the Labor Party over the last 10 years has indicated that it is totally removed from the real world. Parliament has never been held in lower regard. The fact is we have 30 Bills of sufficient importance for the Government to place them on the parliamentary agenda, matters of great moment, which will be virtually jackbooted through this Parliament.

The quality of debate in this new Parliament has no doubt stooped to a very new low because, quite frankly, this guillotine means that 30 pieces of legislation will indeed be voted on without real debate. There will be division after division after division, and there will be no real discussion. The Labor Party, as part of its hidden agenda, as part of constitutional reform—it is not going to tell us openly about this—wants to do away with the Senate. After all, the Prime Minister refers to senators as pansies and unrepresentative swill. What does the Prime Minister intend to do about making the so-called unrepresentative swill more representative? It is part of his agenda to do away with the Senate. The Senate is the house of review, and if ever we need a legitimate reason for a Senate, for a house of review, we only have to look at the Government's practices here. Where would we be as a nation if we did not have a house of review when the Government bulldozes legislation through the House the way these 30 Bills are destined to be bulldozed through over the next few days?

I would like to ask the honourable member for Grayndler (Ms McHugh)—anyone who can do over Leo McLeay deserves respect—why she does not approach the honourable member for Swan and ask him to allow some decent debate here. Why does she not come over here and join us and vote for reasoned and rational discussion? I know that deep down the honourable member for Grayndler believes this place should mean something. I know she does not like it to be used as a rubber stamp; I know she has a basic respect for convention even though she is in the socialist left faction of the ALP. It is usually hard to see how anyone in that faction—yourself excluded, of course, Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins—could possibly have respect for convention. It is a tragedy and a disgrace that this Government has come back here on the third real sitting day and is showing such contempt for basic institutions.

Then again, this is the Government which tried to stop the relevant ceremonies occurring on opening day in the Senate. The Prime Minister in this Government ordered Senator Evans, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, to stand up and give way to him. This is the Government under which, this year, the Parliament will sit for only 12 weeks. Can honourable members believe that this Parliament will be sitting for a period of a mere 12 weeks? I am told that in some other years the Parliament sat for 18 weeks, but it will sit for just 12 weeks this year. Is this the quality of representation and accountability that the honourable member for Lilley talks about ad nauseam in the media? I think it is an absolute disgrace.

Let us look at the great traditions of the Westminster Parliament. I know that this Government does not want to talk about Westminster, and I know that this Government does not like to talk about the wonderful inheritance of parliamentary democracy we have from that place. The Westminster Parliament sits quite regularly. In fact, the Westminster Parliament is a forum for debate. The Westminster Parliament is a place where there is real democracy. I should also take the opportunity to mention that the Westminster Parliament is a place where the role of Speaker has been entrenched as a neutral, impartial person. Indeed, Miss Betty Boothroyd was elected Speaker and as a Labour member she received the support of the House. At Westminster the Labour Party, the Conservative Party and the Social and Liberal Democratic Party have a great respect for the institution of parliament. I wish our Parliament enjoyed similar respect.

Unfortunately, this Government has been here far too long. I do not know whether honourable members saw the car stickers we had on our cars—`10 years is long enough'. It certainly was. I would have thought that after 10 years this Government would have said, `Although we have the numbers, we should extend the parliamentary sitting by a week. We should sit for more civilised hours and we should sit for more days'. After all, this nation has a million people out of work, half a million people on the long-term unemployed list and a massive foreign debt. Twenty-five per cent of our young people are functionally illiterate on leaving primary school. This nation needs a real parliament; it needs people who can represent Australia's 147 constituencies, and those representatives need to be permitted to debate, stand up, and be counted and support democracy.

In this chamber we have the honourable member for Swan; we have my good friend the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca)—and I hope that that does not mean the honourable member for Bowman will miss out on the next ministerial vacancy when the honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall) falls on his sword—

TALK.START.PARA: —Wishful thinking on your part.

—It would be wishful thinking on the part of the honourable member for Bowman for the honourable member for Rankin to fall on his sword. I must say we will endeavour to assist the honourable member in achieving that aim because we think the honourable member for Bowman would certainly make a better Minister than does the honourable member for Rankin. No doubt the honourable member for Bowman would agree. The Government is not well represented in the chamber. The honourable member for Rankin is not here. We have the honourable member for Swan present, the honourable member for Bowman, and the `Leo killer', the honourable member for Grayndler (Ms McHugh). The honourable member for Grayndler is certainly a giant killer. Then we have the ever silent honourable member for Lilley over there in the corner. They are the only four members of the Government in this chamber at a time when we are debating probably the most important motion to come before this House since the Parliament resumed after the election. We have merely four government members who are here during our debate on democracy.
—Typical.
—It is typical, as the honourable member for McPherson points out.

—We have, too, the honourable member for Cowan, who ought not to have uttered a word because he has not yet made his maiden speech. It is terrible that we see only four people from the Government in this place now. But when the division bells ring we will find people coming in one by one until such time as there is a sufficient number of them here to jackboot, to squash, democracy. It is tragic that the members of the Government are so uninterested in this place that only four of them have come in here to sit and listen to the debate. But later, when the division is held, all members of the Government will come in here because they do not support democracy. I think their absolute rejection of convention and of basic democratic decency will achieve for them increased disrespect from the people of Australia.Why do those opposite not come forward with a new set of rules and simply say that, instead of our having to come here on various planes to sit in parliament, we could all sit in our electorate offices and somehow press a little button to register our vote when the division bells ring? We would not even need to come to Canberra.
—They are looking at that now.

—I believe they are. Every step this Government takes is a step towards destroying democracy. This Government should reconsider its position, and I implore the honourable member for Swan, the Leader of the House, to do so. When I last served in this place, he was one of the more reasonable Labor Ministers. He was a person we could talk to. I often felt he probably did not like being sent in here to do the dirty work of Hawke; he now does similar work for the honourable member for Blaxland, the present Prime Minister. Something should be done. The people of Australia are sorely disappointed that in the opening days of a new parliament we do not find reasonable time to debate, nor do we find that honourable members are able to come along here to debate the great issues of the day.

PARA.TAB: Most honourable members in this chamber would have read the Notice Paper; most honourable members would have seen the 30 pieces of legislation which are to come up for debate. It is patently clear that this Government does not have the capacity to dodge the criticism we are directing at it. It is patently clear that the reason this Parliament is being closed down is that the Government had a bad week last week. Every time a member of the Opposition—whether it was the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) or the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer)—went to the dispatch box and proceeded to ask a question, we could see the pathetic expression that flowed across the face of the honourable member for Rankin. He seemed to be saying, `Oh no, not me again'. He got up; he stammered and he stuttered; he was totally lacking in eloquence. Indeed, from the way he was deserted by honourable members on his side of the House, he should know that he does not have a bright future. We saw the bravado of the Prime Minister; we saw his smile and his swagger; we remembered the con tricks on 13 March, which fooled the people of Australia into giving the Government another term. The fact of the matter is that we know—as do the Prime Minister, the Government and the honourable member for Rankin—that the honourable member for Rankin does not have a long and distinguished parliamentary career in the Ministry ahead of him.

With 147 members here to debate these 30 pieces of legislation, the Government should take on board what we are saying. The Government should consider how important it is to have proper, reasoned and rational debate. The Government should look at the fact that only 12 parliamentary sitting weeks are listed; it should look at the fact that politicians in this nation are held in very low esteem and that the Parliament is held in very low esteem. People are disillusioned and disappointed and in fact believe that politicians are out of touch with the thinking of ordinary Australians.

I would ask, in these final seconds of the time available to me, that the Government reconsider its position. Nobody will hold it against it if it decides to be fair, reasonable, rational, democratic, honest, open and accountable because, after all, the matters before us are of great moment. This Parliament is an important institution; it makes vital decisions that affect millions of Australians. I believe the Government has a duty to not only the Opposition but also the institution itself to make this place work. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, in the 10 years that the Australian Labor Party has occupied the government benches I have sat here in opposition. In those 10 years I have watched many a guillotine applied. In fact, I heard the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss) very eloquently point out that in the last Parliament over half of the legislation had been subject to the guillotine. He expressed some indignation at the simple fact that in this Parliament we will sit for only eight days in eight months.

PARA.TAB: I rise now because in the 10 years I have been here I have never seen the guillotine applied as unnecessarily as I am seeing it applied this afternoon. The indignation of members of the coalition is simply because the guillotine is unnecessary. In the best of circumstances the guillotine is a form used by the Government that ought to be used hesitantly, that the Government ought to be reluctant to employ. We are here at the opening of a parliamentary session in which, as the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) stressed, it is intended that we will sit in May and not in June or July, and with debate being subject to the guillotine.

The reason why members on this side of the House are so incensed at this application of the guillotine, the reason why people in the gallery and those who read Hansard ought to be incensed at this application of the guillotine is that it is so unnecessary. In this, the second sitting week of a term in which the Parliament will not even sit in June or July, we are being forced to hurry through legislation which we would like to debate.

Much has been made of the scornful way in which the public treats this chamber, but more should be made of the scornful and derisive way in which the Government treats this chamber and all arguments ventured by the Opposition. Why do I rise to make this impassioned plea when I know that the outcome of this debate is inevitable? Why has the coalition been so anxious to have this decision reversed when it knows that everyone on the other side will vote following party lines? It is simply because debate was never as necessary in Australia as it is in May 1993.

What do we face? We face an unexpected blow-out in the balance of payments. We face a very uncertain economic future. We face a real reluctance by people to get into that which we most need, that is, export markets, a lethargy hardly surprising by private enterprise. They are the very people we most need to soak up the enormous one million unemployed. We who are elected to represent the people of Australia, elected to come into this chamber and put a point of view, find not only that our point of view will be ignored but also that we will lose an opportunity to put it—not because there is no time, but because the Government chooses, by this technique, to curtail parliamentary sittings.

I remember when I was first in this chamber 10 years ago. As a matter of fact I was the only member of the Liberal Party elected in 1983. The then member for Port Adelaide was the Leader of the House. We all had a soft spot for the then member for Port Adelaide, but I will remember until I leave this chamber how he swaggered in here and smiled and said, `We have the numbers'.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, no! He said, `If you have 75 per cent of the votes, you might as well use them'.

—I would suggest to the Leader of the House that the implication is the same. My quote may have been marginally inaccurate, but my point stands. The then member for Port Adelaide swaggered in here and said, `It doesn't matter what you think, we've got the numbers'. That is precisely the experience we are facing this afternoon. Here we have a government with the numbers, a government which chooses to curtail debate, a government which, no matter what we say, will ensure that the question is put and carried.

PARA.TAB: I am elected as the member for Wakefield not merely to represent the Liberal-National Party supporters in Wakefield who voted for me; I am here to represent everybody in Wakefield. Those opposite are not here merely to represent the Australian Labor Party or those who voted sympathetically for the Australian Labor Party; they are in fact elected to represent everybody. Why is the nation frustrated about the way in which this chamber goes about its business? It is not because we make decisions that frustrate them, but because many of them feel that they are without a voice. Our task is to speak up for people, whether they voted for us or not, and provide a voice for democracy right here. This nation is the safety valve of democracy in Australia.

Why is it that Australia is a country in which parliamentarians can freely move about as compared with European countries such as Bosnia-Herzegovina, where democracy has all but disappeared and where confrontation and bloodshed is the norm? It is because the people of Australia feel that here they have a voice in government. It is very important that we cultivate and keep alive the sense of identity that every Australia ought to have with this chamber.

What is the frustration that is emerging, the frustration most clearly expressed in the number of independent candidates who offered themselves for election at the last federal election? It is the frustration of Australians—not those who disagree with us but those who feel that they are not even heard. They feel that they have no voice. They are the people who, frankly, we need to stand up and speak for, to exercise debate and our right to be heard on a range of issues currently facing the Parliament and the nation. Yet, in the face of that, this Government chooses unnecessarily to apply the guillotine.

I say to the Leader of the House that all the Government is doing is increasing the frustration that Australians feel about being not heard. We know it because what we have to say is ignored by the Government. We laid down a package for real reform of the nation and the Government took no notice at all of it. Australians, who are entitled to be heard because they have elected us to office, remain frustrated. The boiling point of the nation is raised because people feel that they are without a voice.

I do not wish to delay the Parliament any longer but I do want to make the point, as has been made by all Opposition speakers, that of all the guillotines I have seen in a decade in this Parliament this is the most unnecessary. It ought to be opposed by members of the coalition and the Government alike.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank honourable members who participated in the discussion. I have been asked in summing up to respond to a number of points that were made by honourable members and I shall do that to the best of my ability.

PARA.TAB: I must say that some of the comments made, in the light of practice elsewhere around the country, do seem a little insincere. The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), who has not stayed for the entirety of this debate, stood up in this place and complained about the fact that the Government was elected a couple of months ago, has come in here for a few weeks of sitting, will come back for the Budget session, and has made only a very small amount of time available for consideration of affairs of state.

We might, however, have taken a leaf out of the book of his State colleagues to whom he renders a great deal of support when the time comes for their elections. They were elected, of course, six weeks before us and have yet to meet. We are told that they will go rocking into the Western Australian Legislative Assembly some time around June, if and when they feel like it. So, if the honourable member has strictures in that regard, he might, as well as delivering them in this House, give his State colleagues a bit of a phone call and suggest to them that there might be one or two things that it is worth their while talking about. Of course, what they are doing in Western Australia is substantially day by day jettisoning every single one of their election promises.

It was said by the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) that we did not pay enough attention to the very detailed policies of our political opponents. I think that we gave them very detailed attention, actually. We gave honourable members opposite the courtesy of a very solid debate during the course of the few months leading up to the last election. The problem for those opposite is that those detailed policies no longer exist—at least in their pristine purity. One of the advantages to those opposite of a period of reflection in June and July will be an opportunity for them to devise a policy. When they get that opportunity—

TALK.START.PARA: —If there are to be sanctimonious stakes in this debate, I think we have heard about an hour's worth of it. Those opposite can cop a bit of it from me if that is their only concern. They will have an opportunity to sit down and reflect on their non-existent policies. In this chamber they lecture us day in and day out when they are sitting now with policies that have some sort of $22 billion funding hole. If they think that they are worth while and ought to be listened to, they might actually do something about that and then they might be taken a little bit seriously; and we might have a thing or two to say to them about that.

PARA.TAB: One of the other rather graceless performances was from the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp), an unsuccessful contestant for Deputy Leader of the National Party, who suggested that the reason for a guillotine was that everybody on this side of the House intended to take off overseas. I have not noticed, when there are parliamentary breaks, an excessive presence of members of the National and Liberal parties in this place when the various parliamentary delegations are overseas. There is also the opportunity to take advantage of an account which is available to backbench members of the Parliament to travel overseas. I have not looked at that account lately, but I do not know that it is underspent by the Liberal Party or the National Party, nor do I note that any of those overseas parliamentary delegations have been ill-attended by members of the Liberal Party and the National Party. Before they try to make a point about this side of the House allegedly pork-barrelling, they should look to their own records.

The other point that was made by the honourable gentleman was that the take-off would be next week. If it is, I shall be very disappointed, because this Parliament is coming back the week after next for consideration of the material that comes forward to us from the Senate. I would hate to sit in this chamber and not see colleagues on the other side of the House or, more particularly, colleagues on my side of the House when it becomes necessary to deal with whatever it is the Senate sends back to us.

I am a bit depressed by the sort of self-loathing that seems to have taken over our honourable members on the other side of the House; there is no need for that. I do not believe that they are members of a house of ill-fame, as one of them characterised their situation. I do not believe that they are jokes, as two of them characterised their position, nor do I believe that this place treats them as a joke. Again referring to the unsuccessful contestant for Deputy Leader of the National Party, on the subject of parliamentary chairmen, he sought to deride them on the grounds that for the work they did as parliamentary chairmen they get an extra allowance of about $10,000 a year. Those positions actually exist because of one of the very substantial changes which has taken place in the way in which the affairs of this House have been conducted, courtesy of this Government. Far from disrespecting the House of Representatives, it is this Government that has put in place, enshrined in Standing Orders, a whole series of policy committees and surveilled policy activities. Certainly as a Minister who has had dealings with one or two of those committees, they have met to discuss items that I have sent to them; they have arrived at conclusions on items that have been sent to them; and many of those items, arrived at as a result of bipartisan decision making, have been implemented to my certain knowledge by the Government. So, far from being irrelevant, that is one of the many attributes of this Government's attitude towards the Parliament, which shows that we do not have the contempt for it that the Opposition seems to feel we have.

As I said, many of those opposite seriously believe that we have that contempt. There is an element of self-loathing here which is very worrying and troubling to me. We have three years to go before the next election and I would hate them to exist in that state of psychological disrepair. If we are to put up with those opposite in this place operating with that state of psychological disrepair for another three years, there is only so much nursemaiding that we can do.

The other point that arises from the fact that this Government does not feel contempt for this Parliament but respects it greatly is that we do have a very extensive arrangement now in place for the creation of private members business. The honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) asked why we operated the guillotine. Let me confess that we do operate the guillotine far more frequently than the Opposition has ever done, although the guillotine was devised, I think, by a conservative government and certainly perfected by the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) when he was Manager of Government Business. I always have a feeling, as I stand here and move the guillotine, that still resident in the House is the patron saint of guillotines. As he is the patron saint of this entire process, I always pay slight homage to whatever corner the National Party leaves him in as it works him up to the ultimate element of the back bench. Having assumed that position, we ought always in these guillotine debates show proper deference to a great parliamentarian for having invented it.

The reason we have had recourse to the guillotine and have not had recourse to closure in the way in which those opposite did for a time is that there has been a very substantial change in the sitting patterns. Honourable members will find—this year being an exception, as an election year always is—as they examine the non-election years that the numbers of days on which the Parliament sits is virtually no different from the time of the Fraser Government or governments before then. Those opposite need to ask themselves: when we have the same number of days each year that the Parliament sits, why does the Government keep moving a guillotine? The answer to that is quite interesting, if they have ever bothered to ask themselves that question. The answer lies partly in the amount of time we allow for private business.

When I came to this place, general business Thursday beyond the first two Thursdays in a sitting never took place. There would be notices of motion for general business Thursday which would stay on the Notice Paper for the entire parliament. General business Thursday disappeared and was taken over exclusively by government legislation. That is the first notable difference—because we do not treat this Parliament with contempt and, particularly, we do not treat backbenchers and private members business with contempt.

The second reason that we sit as often as we did previously but have a guillotine applied more rigorously is the application of time limits on sittings. Even with the guillotine, we do not sit much past 12.30 of a night. When I first came to this place we regularly sat until 3 or 4 o'clock in the morning, even though the 11 o'clock rule had been put in place by the Whitlam Government. So the second reason that we do have these extensive guillotines is that the Government is reluctant to sit the Parliament night after night until 3 or 4 o'clock in the morning.

The third reason why we sit as much as we did before but have more frequent recourse to the guillotine is the way in which those days were arrived at. It is easy for those opposite to trip off their lips, `Well, we will sit seven days only in the month', and then carry that through into an analysis month by month and say at the end of the period, `That is only 70-odd days'. This Parliament decided that pattern: honourable members had responsibilities in their constituencies; the parliamentary committee system was then more well-developed and there needed to be opportunities for those committees effectively to be able to operate—those parliamentary committees do not sit while Parliament is sitting—and the business is, if you like, on the side of the entire Parliament. The Government also found it convenient and useful because of the great deal more burdensome task of budgetary formulation. Our Government operates by committee much more extensively than did our opponents.

What the old system did was this: when it was three weeks on one week off, albeit with only three days in each of those three weeks—it is now three days and four days and then two weeks off—a frequent Friday sitting would be made possible by the fact that there was only a three-day sitting. As well as the frequent Friday sitting, honourable members were much more cavalier with the 11 o'clock rule than we were. So the combination of all those factors, whilst producing no formal increase in the number of sitting days, created an enormous capacity to expand time at the expense of the health and the participation of the backbench members of Parliament.

If those opposite do not like that, they need to sit down and think it through. If they sit down and look through the timetables of the various sittings of the Parliament, they will find a couple of days in the year at a time they were on this side of the House when they sat more often than we did. But they will not find the difference is weeks or months; they will find the difference is a few days. That might indicate the odd one or two sitting weeks at the very maximum, but they will not always find that. I have gone into the reasons why they will not find that to be the case.

This legislation has been guillotined not because we fear the new composition of the Senate; every item is on this list because of a midyear start-up date. It does not look as though that is the case with some of the Bills on that list because they address sunset clause issues. While it looks as though some Bills are just a continuation of something that has existed before, if that is not the case, they will drop out. We do not particularly fear the composition of the Senate and, even if we did, we could do very little about it over the next few weeks.

Much of this material is very important legislation; it includes the wool legislation which, importantly, will substantially benefit wool producers. But the fact of the matter is those wool producers will want a conclusion by the end of next month. They will not get a conclusion by the end of next month unless this legislation goes to the Senate in the next couple of weeks. While the Government does not have the numbers in the Senate, and the Opposition does, there is a tendency to go through the legislation at a fairly leisurely bat. That consideration must be concluded by the middle of this year.

The Opposition has asked for an explanation of why the Government has put a guillotine in place. This is the explanation. No other government of this country will be able to operate on any other basis unless it substantially cuts into private members' time; alters the two week on, two week off sitting pattern to something like it was before; and, having altered that two week on, two week off sitting pattern, it would then have to suspend the 11 o'clock rule massively and continuously and add additional days' sittings in the process. If that is what Opposition members want, they had better stand up and say so. But, as I remember it, Ric Charlesworth's reforms went through with the unanimous support of this Parliament.
