Tangney, the electorate I represent, is an inner metropolitan electorate straddling the leafy southern suburbs of Perth. It is largely a residential area with some light industry. The northern boundary is formed by the southern sides of the Swan and Canning rivers. It is named after Dame Dorothy Tangney. Her career was detailed and the electorate was described as it then was in the maiden speech of my immediate predecessor, Mr Peter Shack. The warm welcome I have received from the residents of Tangney as their new representative has been humbling. I thank them and the many people whose efforts ensured my election.

Tangney has sent four representatives to Canberra before me. Mr Peter Shack made a substantial contribution to public life over many years, a contribution which has not, in my view, been acknowledged adequately. Mention could be made of two other former representatives. Both occupy positions on the government front bench: one as Treasurer and the other as Assistant Treasurer. Despite being rejected by it, the latter, the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear), is so attached to the electorate of Tangney that he continues to reside in it. In fact, his residence is within a very short distance of my electorate office. I want to assure the Assistant Treasurer that if he, as one of my constituents, ever has any problem with the Federal Government or any of its instrumentalities, the services of my electorate office are available to assist him. This applies particularly to any difficulty he might encounter in his relationship with the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) or the Department of the Treasury.

Mr Speaker, in giving the call to new members for the first time, just as you did with me, you have requested the House to extend the usual courtesies. This is a laudable practice which enables new members unfamiliar with the House and its ways to crawl before they are called upon to walk. The price exacted of a new member for the courtesies is that he or she is expected to be non-contentious. In the past week there have been some instances of new members accepting the courtesies and sailing close to the limits of non-contention. The non-contentious remarks of one new member caused a member of long standing to exercise his right to give a personal explanation in reply to criticism of him.

In my view, it is wrong that courtesy should be abused. It would undermine the practice of allowing a new member to speak undisturbed and could result in the practice being dropped. In case anything I will say might be considered by others to be contentious, let me say that I will not complain if honourable members feel able to curb their natural propensity for courtesy. I will not complain if I am treated as if I am delivering a second speech rather than a maiden speech.

The reason why a person deeply immersed in a business, profession or in particular employment decides to leave that calling and offer himself or herself for election to parliament is usually complex. In my case, significant factors were that I was concerned about the decisions being taken for Australia and the direction those decisions were taking the country.

Another significant factor which influenced my decision was my view of the way the decisions affecting the nation and its people were being taken in parliament. My perception, and one which I shared with many Australians, was that the Parliament was a place in which entertainment, derision and abuse featured at the expense of rational debate. Whether or not that perception was accurate, it is one of my aspirations to participate in the decision making of this House by contributing to a reasoned discussion of issues.

I seek to contribute to a process which all Australians can be confident enables the serious, substantive questions facing Australia to be properly dealt with on their merits. The serious issues which presently require urgent attention remain the same as they were before the election. I add that the urgent issues do not include the issue of a republic.

My parents grew up in the 1920s. I was a teenager growing up in the 1950s. My children are teenagers now. My parents lived through the Great Depression and, before recovery from that was complete, the Second World War. Neither had the opportunity to finish school. In their youth, opportunities for employment were limited. In my youth, Australia was a place of great stability and of great optimism. Education was both available and free, and finding a job was not difficult. With hindsight, there was much that could have been improved, but at the time most Australians thought they had a fortunate life in a lucky country.

Like many of the electors of Tangney, I am concerned about the future of my children. I want young Australians to be able to look forward to an appropriate education of their choice and to have the prospect of getting a job. One of my goals is for Australia again to become an economically stable country in which the people have corresponding opportunities for education and employment that the youth of my generation had, or believed they had.

The parliament is the crucible in which the essence of our democracy is distilled. The democracy, however, derives not only from the parliament. The complex relationships of the legislative, executive and judicial arms of government form the foundations, and the powers which each arm of government exercises ultimately depend not on any coercive capacity but on the support, express or tacit, given to it by the public.

In the early 1970s I was employed by the Asian Development Bank and my wife and I lived in the Philippines, a nation then proud of its democracy established after the war. In September 1972 we had a vivid demonstration of the fragility of democracy. We woke on a Sunday morning to find that there was no newspaper. The radio, with its innumerable stations, was silent. The television ran no programs. We found the roads were almost empty. A policeman on a motorbike stopped our car. He was unable to explain to us what was happening, but did indicate there was a curfew. Later that day we learned that, having on Saturday night been living in a democracy with presidential elections approaching, we were now on Sunday living ostensibly under constitutional martial law with elections suspended. In fact, we were under a militarily backed dictatorship.

My work took me to many Asian countries. What I saw made me realise how fortunate Australians are. In many countries there was no suggestion of democracy; in a number there was war or insurgency. Even in those Asian countries with democratic governments substantially based on the Westminster system there were subtle differences from our system. Those subtle differences can determine whether there is a genuinely free democracy or one in which there is no defence to repression.

An essential element of a true democracy, of our democracy, is an independent judiciary. I do not suggest that Australia's democratic system is presently under direct threat, but Australians should always be vigilant to ensure that any threat to the independence of our judiciary is firmly challenged. The independence involves freedom of the judiciary from the influence, by fear, favour or otherwise, of any agency and particularly the executive government. Essential to the independence of the judiciary is a strong, independent legal profession. The role and functioning of the legal profession continues as a subject of public discussion. In those discussions, the importance of the profession in the maintenance of the judicial system should be neither underestimated nor undermined.

Intrinsic to the performance by this House of ensuring government is accountable to the people is the principle that no member should mislead the House. In a similar way, the efficient administration of justice depends on members of the legal profession as officers of the superior courts not misleading any court. In parliamentary elections, there is no equivalent obligation, and the opportunities for distortion and deception are abundant. In practical terms, the means of preventing dissemination of misleading information and the means of remedying the consequences of it are quite inadequate. This is particularly the case where those involved are not candidates or are not acting in the name of a political party. That, in my opinion, constitutes a significant potential threat to democracy. It is a matter, in my view, which warrants the attention of the Parliament.

In responding to the proposed Address-in-Reply, I wish to refer to some specific matters. First, the Constitution of Australia provides for this to be a constitutional monarchy. The Government has no mandate from the electorate for a change from a constitutional monarchy to a republic. Australians can indicate their desire for such a change only by a referendum. Historically, Australians have shown themselves to be very reluctant to amend the Constitution. In those circumstances, it would be presumptuous for anybody to assume what would be the result of a referendum proposing that Australia should be a republic. It would be even more presumptuous to assert what sort of republic Australians would accept.

The Opposition is committed to participating in the debate over whether Australia should become a republic and, if the answer is yes, what sort of republic Australia should become. It is essential that the public be informed fully as to what are the alternative forms of republic. It is also essential that there be a detailed analysis in the course of the public debate of the advantages and disadvantages of the alternatives—retention of the constitutional monarchy, variation of it or substitution of one of a number of possible forms of republic.

It has not escaped attention that the Government appears to have embarked on a subtle campaign to remove visible references to and symbols of the monarchy. That campaign has extended to matters concerned with this Parliament. As I understand it, the proclamation of the Governor-General calling Parliament together has, since 1901, been in a time-honoured form. The proclamation has traditionally concluded with the words, `God save the Queen'. The proclamation calling this Parliament together omitted those words.

The forms of oath and affirmation of office taken by Ministers have also been in a time-honoured form. The commitment under it has been well and truly to serve the Queen, her heirs and successors according to law in the relevant office. Just prior to this Parliament being opened, the form of oath and affirmation of office was changed. In consequence, the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) took an oath of office different from that taken by other Ministers. Reference to the Queen was eliminated.

The traditional form of Address-in-Reply to the Governor-General's speech has for 90 years been substantially in the same form. The Address-in-Reply proposed last week by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the honourable member for Lowe (Ms Easson) and the honourable member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) is not in that traditional form. While reference to the sovereign has not been eliminated, it has been amended.

For my part, I have no difficulty with changing the language of forms with a view to simplifying or modernising the language. It is particularly appropriate where the traditional form is obscure and the replacement, without changing the effect, is simple and direct. It is another thing, however, for the traditional forms to be changed with the object of eliminating references to our present constitutional system, the monarchy, with the ultimate view, no doubt, of inculcating and promoting a republican ideal.

Australia may in the future become a republic, but if it does Australia will not become a republic by stealth. The Australian people cannot be taken for granted. Australia has a constitution. Until Australians agree to its being changed, it should not be subverted; it should be observed.

In the Governor-General's speech, reference was made to gender awareness programs for members of the judiciary and other decision makers within the legal system. I refer to this because of its connection with the independence of the judiciary.

Historically, there have been aspects of our law which were structured in such a way that they did not take into account women's perspectives adequately or, in some cases, at all. Reform over decades has eliminated much of that imbalance, but it would be wrong to assume that none remains.

Justice is administered in courts by judges and by judges and juries. Australians have a judiciary which is the equal of any in the common law world, and the public has great faith in the jury system. One of the strengths of the judiciary is that the judges exercise their responsibilities free from the influences of government and free from sectional and community influences. The function of a judge is largely to declare and apply the law. However, some decisions may be affected by the judge's personal view on a social issue. This may be true of juries also, but their deliberations are in private.

From time to time, a judge sitting in court evinces an attitude which the community finds unacceptable. There have been notable instances recently where judges in sexual assault trials have made comments which many in the community, and particularly women, have found demeaning of women. I expressly refrain from commenting on any particular case. It is certainly disappointing if a judge reveals an attitude which is out of date or unenlightened or is out of step with general community views. It is more than disappointing if that attitude affects the outcome of a case before the judge, such that the outcome is perceived as unjust. I accept that many women in the community are concerned that some male judges have outdated attitudes on some social issues that do not adequately reflect the community viewpoint, particularly that of women.

What should be done? It must not be forgotten that many decisions of judges are subject to appeal and an appellate court may correct a decision which reflects an inappropriate attitude on the part of a trial judge. That is not a complete solution. It is not for the Government to take steps to indoctrinate or re-educate judges. That would give rise to different and very serious concerns. It is for the judiciary itself to do something. In relation to gender bias awareness, the fact is that the judiciary has recognised that there is a need for something to be done. In the absence of detail in the Governor-General's speech, one could be forgiven for thinking that the proposed funding of the gender awareness programs for the judiciary was an initiative of the Government. It is not. The Government is responding to an initiative of the Australian Institute of Judicial Administration.

The institute is a body independent of government, comprising a large number of judges, magistrates, lawyers—in private practice, in government practice and academics—and court administrators dedicated to the study and improvement of the system of administration of justice. In November 1992 the institute, having regard to the report of the task force of the National Committee on Violence Against Women, applied to the Government for funding for the development of a gender bias awareness program. The institute is an appropriate body to develop and to conduct such courses for the judiciary. On the basis that there is no government interference in the development conduct of any such courses, I expect the Opposition would in due course support the provision of funds by the Government to the institute for the project.

It is pleasing also to note that the institute is conducting a program on Aboriginal cultural awareness for the judiciary and is investigating the introduction of both gender bias and Aboriginal cultural awareness programs into orientation courses for judicial officers. I am aware that at least one State Supreme Court, the Supreme Court of Western Australia, is arranging its own gender bias awareness courses for its judges.
Mr Speaker, I congratulate you on your election. This House is engaged in important work for the people of Australia. I look forward to participating in that work in a meaningful and productive way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the honourable member for Corio, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's first speech and I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

—I am very proud to rise in this place tonight as the new member for Corio, and I am really pleased to be here representing the Australian Labor Party, the oldest political party and the greatest political party in Australia today. Mr Speaker, may I extend my thanks to the people of Geelong and the electors of Corio for the great honour they have extended to me by sending me here to represent their interests in the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: It is a wonderful electorate. They are wonderful people; I guess it is not fashionable for politicians to make promises at this point in our history, but I will make only one and that is that I will faithfully serve their interests in this Parliament. I will bring all my skill and energy to bear to represent their interests and I hope at the end of the day, when I leave this House, people will be able to say that he did his best for Geelong.

At this stage, I would like to pay tribute to the man who preceded me as member for Corio in this House, the Hon. Gordon Glen Denton Scholes. As honourable members would know, Gordon entered the Parliament in 1967 and, over a career that spanned some 26 years, he gave loyal service to his constituents and loyal service to this Parliament. He was a man of integrity and he was genuinely liked by people on both sides of the House.

Can I just take honourable members through some of the elements of his maiden speech, because it will give them some idea of the vision of this man whom I regard as one of the unsung heroes of the labour movement over the past 30 years. In his maiden speech, Gordon drew attention to the fact that Australia needed a national standard gauge network. He also drew attention to the fact that Australia needed a universal health system easily affordable, a quality system that would serve the working people of Australia. He also made reference, in his maiden speech, to the need for a government aircraft production facility in Australia, and I am pleased to say that it was Labor in government that delivered those things to him. The national standard gauge network, as part of the One Nation statement, will be routed through Geelong. The Government has instituted a Medicare system that is the envy of the world. This Government provided the finance for the restructuring of the Government Aircraft Corporation which has lead to the formation of ASTA, which offers great and exciting potential for employment growth in the Geelong region.

It was a great contribution that he made to this place. I think the measure of his status can be seen in what other great Australians thought of Gordon. I would like to recount to honourable members an incident that occurred in the course of the campaign. We invited the living Labor legend, Big Gough, down to Corio to assist us in the campaign. It was a hot night, and we were all sweating pretty badly. The big fellow was mopping the back of the head like so. The city of Geelong West provided a small reception in the anteroom. After that was completed I suggested to Gough and Gordon that, before we went to the main dinner, we might like to go outside and walk up the side of the Geelong West Town Hall. We did that, to catch a bit of fresh air before we went into the main dinner.

As we walked along, Gordon was railing against the effect of the GST on older Australians. It was something that he felt quite passionate about, particularly the effect of the GST on funerals. As we got near the entrance to the main hall the Big Fellow stopped. We both stopped and he looked at Gordon and me; it was a poignant historical moment for me; and he said, `Well, Gordon, you and I will not have to worry about that. There will be no GST on state funerals'.

I think it was a mark of how Gough perceived Gordon's contribution to the nation, as well as how Gough perceived his own historical importance to the nation. But Gordon's contribution was a magnificent one, and I am sure all members on both sides of the House will join me in wishing him well in his retirement. He will be retiring from this place, but not from active political life in Geelong.

Mr Speaker, the great Corio electorate, which I now represent, stretches from the great industrial heartland of the north of the electorate—the suburbs of Corio: Norlane and North Shore—and sweeps down along the Princes Highway to the central business district which services the great west coast region and the Bellarine Peninsula and also the productive western district hinterland. It is an electorate rich in ethnic diversity. It also stretches from that central business district down along the Bellarine peninsula. In that central business district that I mentioned before is the city's great cultural assets. I refer here to the Geelong Art Gallery, the Geelong Performing Arts Centre and the National Wool Museum. All these initiatives have been funded by State and Federal Labor governments to serve the people of this great region of Australia.

Corio is an electorate of great ethnic diversity. I pay tribute here to the people who came to Geelong in the postwar era to make their homes. They have made an enormous contribution to the economic, social and cultural development of this region. We have one of the great community festivals in Geelong, the Pako Festa, and it is unique because it involves the combined effort of local government, the business community and the ethnic community. The Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) had the pleasure of participating in that festival in the course of the campaign.

It is also an electorate endowed with great physical infrastructure assets. As far as transport is concerned, the port of Geelong is one of the pre-eminent bulk handling ports in Australia. It has recently undergone a period of micro-economic reform, resulting in great increases in productivity without conflict. It is well serviced by rail, and I have already mentioned the standard gauge rail network supplementing that service. It is well serviced by road. Travelling from Melbourne to Geelong, one can see the One Nation moneys being spent on upgrading the roads. Down on the Bellarine Peninsula, the Portarlington Road is almost complete. It is also well serviced by air. Exciting developments are taking place at Avalon with ASTA becoming a major regional employer and offering great potential for expansion.

The region also has a well-developed community services sector. I would like to pay particular tribute tonight to those much maligned people in the Australian community who provide an essential range of services to the people of Geelong to improve their standard of living.

As far as the business sector is concerned, we have a combination of large industry: Ford, which produces passenger motor vehicles; textiles, clothing and footwear, with Godfrey Hirst Carpets; Alcoa, which produces aluminium; and also Shell, which produces petroleum. The large business sector is particularly important to the Geelong region; but so is the small business sector, and I will speak further about that a little later.

Many words have been spoken in recent times about the problems that the city of Geelong has had in the past. The Pyramid collapse sapped community confidence. Industry restructuring has meant that there has been significant labour shedding in the passenger motor vehicles industry and the textiles, clothing and footwear industry. There has also been a major impact upon the city with the general downturn in manufacturing. However, through all that, the great, resilient Geelong community has come through the pain and it now faces the future with a degree of optimism. It is a great place to live and a great place to be, and it is bristling with potential. Many people have asked what that potential is. I would suggest that, in the range of government programs that have been put in place, there are hints as to the areas in which the Geelong economy can grow over the next decades.

Food and fibre processing will become increasingly significant. I would like to pay particular tribute to the Federal Government for the encouragement that it gave to BWK, the German wool scourer, to locate in the region. It will mean an extra 150 private sector jobs. There is great potential for job creation in the Geelong region through tourism—general tourism, eco-tourism, rural tourism and cultural tourism—utilising all the assets I have mentioned. There is great potential in the area for the export of services. I refer to engineering, construction and educational services. There is also potential for further growth in the public sector. Corio is relatively underdone when compared to other electorates around Australia in that regard. All in all, it is an exciting place to be and one which offers great potential.

I wish to turn to the sector of the Geelong economy which offers the key to its long-term economic future and growth in jobs. I refer to the development of Geelong's small and medium business sector and the commercialisation of the new, innovative technologies that exist in the region. Exports from the Magnificent 700, identified by the Australian Manufacturing Council, will grow to $15 billion by 1997. My aim over the next three years will be to make sure that innovative Geelong businesses get a big slice of the action. Sorry, guys!

I applaud the recent measures announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) which are designed to strengthen and encourage small business. Competitive taxation arrangements, investment and export incentives will do much to stimulate that sector. The Government's recent initiatives to make the banking and finance sector more responsive to the needs of small and medium business, and to expand their lending to promising new ventures, is good news. However, there is more to be done. Conservative banks are still attempting to shore up losses incurred throughout the 1980s.

I would like to draw the attention of the House to an innovative firm in Geelong called Gearing Dynamics. It has developed a revolutionary oil-emersed braking system which has quite staggering export potential. While the company has struggled to research and develop the product and to bring it to the commercialisation phase, it has encountered significant bureaucratic and financial institutional inertia that really leaves one wondering about the future of the clever country. While the bankers muse about the great potential of the product, it is their guidelines that restrict lending to commercialise the product.

There is much more to be done in the area of financing small, innovative businesses. Ways must be found to encourage the mobilisation of indigenous capital in regional areas. Joint venture risk capital companies need to be encouraged with principals who are not constrained by the largely conservative lending culture that still exists in the Australian banking system. It is only when these problems are really addressed that the clever country can ride on the back of the innovative energy of its entrepreneurs.

I would like to turn now to the area of regional development, an issue which has important ramifications for Geelong. I suggest that there is a role for the Commonwealth Government to play in stimulating the efficient use of national resources, as well as reducing the disparity in income levels and living standards between regions. National economic and welfare objectives cannot be fulfilled if key manufacturing regions such as Geelong are not performing to their potential. Market forces alone will not achieve the optimal spatial distribution of industry across the Australian economy.

There are several compelling reasons why we need to seriously examine the regional development issue now. Firstly, the rapid pace of structural adjustment has left many regions with a diminished capacity to absorb displaced labour. Secondly, our major cities are becoming less attractive places to live. They have become economically inefficient, socially remote and polluted environments. In many regions the process of economic decline has been exacerbated by the process of tariff reform, adverse climatic conditions and declining commodity prices, which have served to reduce production, employment and income flows in local communities. In addition, the process of micro-economic reform has led to significant losses of public employment in smaller provincial towns that have no economic capacity to employ displaced skills. This rapid and serious decline in the economic base of regions threatens current and future investment in community assets such as housing and roads.

I applaud the Government's recent regional policy initiatives: the expansion of DITAC to include regional development responsibilities and the imminent formation of a regional development task force. There is a need to develop a comprehensive policy framework for coordinating existing Commonwealth programs, for many initiatives in the food processing and tourism area, labour market and adjustment programs, assistance to exporters and rural economic programs impact significantly on regions. The policy framework that is being developed must allow sufficient flexibility to accommodate the different responses that are required to meet the unique problems and needs of differing regions. It must also coordinate in an effective way all the players in the game—local and State governments, regional development associations, the union movement, community organisations and private firms. I look forward to participating in this future debate.

Now let me turn to an issue which will occupy a central place in public debate in Australia in coming years. I refer to the issue of an Australian republic. This is the debate that the Australian people have to have. I appreciate that the issue is a sensitive one for many Australians, because I draw my family heritage from English, Irish and Scottish ancestry, but that should not prevent us from conducting this debate in a rational manner.

I see great potential for this debate to unlock the creative energy of Australians and to define more clearly for us what it means to be Australian in this rapidly changing world. The factors that are propelling us towards this debate are compelling. Since World War II the influx of migrants from southern Europe, and more recently from Asia, has created a cultural and ethnic diversity unparalleled in our previous history. Also, an increasing regional identification has been encouraged by the growth of our trade with rapidly expanding Asian economies to our north. Just as the United Kingdom is seeking to carve out a deeper economic and political relationship with Europe, so must Australia seek to construct a more meaningful relationship with our northern neighbours. Just as the loyalty of the Queen of England will always be to her own subjects in the United Kingdom, so must we have in Australia a truly Australian head of state whose pre-eminent loyalty will be to the people of this nation.

I think it is fair to say that there is widespread community confusion and ignorance about the Australian Constitution, the federal system and the institutions at the core of our political system. Therefore, we must grasp this historical opportunity to open up debate on the future of our political institutions and structures.

I reiterate the Prime Minister's invitation to honourable members opposite to participate fully in this great national debate, and commend the Prime Minister for his political courage in thrusting this issue to the centre of the political stage. In raising this issue the Prime Minister is articulating a deep and legitimate personal aspiration. But it is one which I believe he now shares with a majority of Australians. I am convinced that we can conduct this debate in a way that gives all Australians an opportunity to participate, that strengthens our democratic system, and that produces an outcome that reflects our current political, economic and social maturity—an Australian republic.

I come to this House as the son of parents who were small dairy farmers and onion growers, and I owe my presence in this place to the magnificent upbringing I enjoyed on our small farm at the base of Red Rock at Alvie and the Warrion Hills in the western district of Victoria. My parents were committed Christians and lived by what they preached. They instilled in their four children an intense love of the land, care for one's fellow man, the need to contribute to one's community no matter what one's station in life, and perhaps most of all that the pursuit of material wealth for its own sake was the path of fools. They were both humble and proud, and lived their working lives with great dignity. I owe them, and my brother and sisters much.

I joined the Labor Party because it offered me the opportunity to politically express the great values of my upbringing. The party's unswerving commitment to the disadvantaged, its great egalitarian traditions and its fundamental commitment to genuine reform in pursuit of fairness and equity provide a natural political home for those who thirst for justice and who seek to construct a better Australia.

To the Geelong branches of the ALP my thanks for their enduring support throughout the course of the campaign. To the great Geelong trades hall—one of the great progressive forces in Geelong society today—my thanks for its commitment and support throughout the campaign that brought me to this place. To my close friends who have shared the journey with me, providing wise counsel and support along the way, I thank them sincerely—especially to the General and to the late nights when we sat over wine, biting the heads off the chooks. That is code for getting up to a little bit of political scheming.

Mr Deputy Speaker, may I wish you and Speaker Martin all the very best in your new roles. My predecessor in this place, Gordon Scholes, had a great respect for the Parliament. He loved the Parliament and he loved its procedures. I hope I will grow to have the same love of this Parliament that my predecessor had. I thank honourable members for their indulgence. (Time expired)
Honourable members—Hear, hear!

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Before I call the honourable member for Grey, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's first speech and I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Grey is 92 per cent of the land mass of South Australia, running south to Clare, and is much larger than New South Wales. Mr Deputy Speaker, as the 10th member for Grey, I offer my support for your adjudication in this place. I come from a small community called Kimba—Aboriginal for `bushfire'—founded earlier this century, and typical of hundreds of such communities around Australia struggling valiantly to survive against the huge odds of centralisation, high indirect taxation and careless government.

PARA.TAB: I thank the electors of Grey for an opportunity to serve them in the Federal Parliament. I thank the hundreds of campaign workers and supporters for their help. The work has just begun for us—particularly for me. Thank you to my wife Christine, and to Catherine, James and Matthew who worked hard for my election, if nothing else to get me off the farm, and to Daniel who is with his mother in the gallery tonight. Thank you to Donna and James Siegele for being with us, and for coming down from Sydney, and to Andrew and Sarah. Thank you to mother, Una, and father, Gordon, and my three brothers and two sisters who all had a hand in my political education. Hello to Tennant Creek and Gympie. I thank the people of Wakefield without whose faith my task would have been impossible. The honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), Senator Ferguson and Senator Chapman provided invaluable support.

Today I think of the electorate of Grey with its multiculturism which goes back over 150 years—at Port Pirie, the people from Mortetta, the 50 to 60 nationalities of Whyalla, Port Augusta and Port Lincoln, and places such as Nunjikompita, Mudamuckla, Buckleboo, Mintabie and the Pangkala Aboriginal people who were the earliest known inhabitants of my region. I think of Benno Murray, at 103 years of age the oldest known Aboriginal—a Gallipoli and World War II veteran, and a resident of Womi Kata at Port Augusta. Grey spans from Broken Hill to Eucla and from Port Lincoln to Birdsville.

I note the last Liberal member for Grey, Don Jessop's enthusiasm for Whyalla in his first speech some twenty-six years ago, where he noted a population in 1967 of 22,000 and rising. I understand it went to 36,000 in the early 1970s and is back to somewhere near the 1967 numbers today—1993. In that speech Don Jessop spoke about Woomera and its activity, and that stands in some contrast to today's Woomera and its battle to maintain its population.

No electorate in Australia goes without its railways, and there is a great history in the railways of Grey. At Peterborough we see the evidence of our history with the various railway gauges with which most members in the House would be familiar. The irony is that Australian National has been the leader in Australia's rail industry and now appears under significant threat. I will continue to inquire of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) and seek a clear explanation of the future of Port Augusta and the Eyre Peninsula line, to at least ensure a consultative process where people are not living in a constant state of insecurity. I understand the Minister has had some distractions presently.

I am, for all intents and purposes, a member of a union, and I have difficulty understanding all the breast-beating about the solidarity of the workers, when I reckon I can shear a sheep as well as most opposite, shift the concrete, work in a foundry, or whatever, and I have done it. I look forward to a less confrontationist, less adversarial industrial system; in fact an industrial system that works in Australia's interest and is not governed by narrow partisan interests.

We can only make progress as an independent nation if we recognise that we are an interdependent society. Australia is not a one-party nation, as the last election conclusively showed: 1,279 Australians in eight marginal seats determined the outcome of the election. In 11 million people that is a much narrower victory than any one-point victory in an Australian rules football grand final, and surely even the most one-eyed Labor supporter must regard it as a very slim mandate.

I can remember when Prime Ministers would claim victory in the spirit of governing for all Australians, but I do not recall hearing that this time around. The great lesson of 1993 was the use of fear as a legitimate political weapon, and I note the main headline today about the Government's need to broaden the tax base. My opinion is clear—Parliament must restore its credibility and show leadership, and insist on truth in political advertising.

Grey has an unemployment rate about 50 per cent above the national statistics for the bigger centres, and I note that the first speech of my predecessor, Lloyd O'Neil, 10 years ago was in a similar vein. I see or hear no sign of any improvement, and it gives me no joy to say that. We are fortunate to have Roxby Downs, Moomba, our opal fields, our iron ore, and our gypsum mines, but that is still not enough. The infrastructure and our natural resources which the people of Grey currently produce means we make up about 50 per cent of South Australia's exports. The full potential is thwarted by a heavy indirect taxation burden. We must encourage people to help themselves, but we can never reach our potential if we tax people excessively before they even strike a blow.

High wages are not necessarily a guarantee of good results or quality management. The State Bank of South Australia stands as a sad testimony to that reality. I am a supporter of the old Frank Crean story about one person's pay rise being another person's job. I believe Clyde Cameron, whom I know personally and whose company I have enjoyed, is of a similar opinion. It is not the dollars in the pocket that counts; it is what the dollars will buy which is the bottom line for most Australians.

We have not given our youth, in my opinion, as sound an opportunity as I was given in my country, and I am distressed by what I see around me—the lack of opportunities and improvements for these capable people. We have a responsibility in Parliament and as a nation to hand this country on in at least as good a shape as we found it.

Rational economics implies that anyone who differs with your opinion lacks a social conscience. Of course, we must not debate anything that this Government says is off limits. I prefer rational economics to irrational economics, and particularly after the national headlines today about increased taxation.

I come to our senior citizens. I respect the foundations that our senior citizens have laid and the sacrifices and contributions they have made; their humour; their generosity; their wisdom; and their leadership.

Small business needs encouragement as employment generators and positive contributors to our economy. They are the most neglected powerhouse for changing our situation for a positive future. It is a simple matter of the enterprise ethic; the will, the strength within individual Australians, to create and build and get the job done.

I turn now to research and development. I have a particular interest in water quality and water usage, in alternative energy, and particularly in the blockages to our making more of our own inventions as an Australian economy.

I come to the matter of the republic, and I will be brief. The main constitutional concern stated by the Government is to have an Australian head of state chosen by Australians. I understand that Bill Hayden is an Australian and that he was chosen by Australians; therefore, why the inferiority complex?

I turn now to conservation. Part of my electorate includes the Lake Eyre basin. It is currently perceived by some to be under threat from a World Heritage listing. Locking this land up for the long term is seen as a threat to the viability of pastoralism and as a huge cost to taxpayers. I await with interest the Minister's plan for this region. We also have Landcare. I was involved in the early days of Landcare and the Phillip Toyne/Rick Farley initiative, but there is still a great unfinished job to be done. It has achieved a lot, but I outline this simple equation: something like $150 per farm is given from the Government, from the Treasury, and we take something like $15,000 to $30,000—you name it—out of that same farm by way of indirect taxation. So I suggest that one of the biggest threats to conservation in this country is the economic pressure of government policies.

I deal now with industrial relations. Industrial relations has a long tradition of adversarial competition which has harmed Australia's potential, and I look forward to the day when this part of Australia's national life is bipartisan and not captive to the partisan interests. It is ironic to listen to the Government and the unions after the election embracing aspects of our policy after the attacks made by many, including the teachers unions and the nurses federation, in a disgracefully dishonest fear campaign.

I turn now to education. Austudy and many components of Austudy are unfair to many who live long distances from the main centres of learning. There is some irony in the fact that we need people to live in our regions to produce most of our export income, but when it comes to a fair go in services the Parliament does not hear. It is a serious issue. At a time when we need all the skills this country can offer, there are too many people missing out.

The next serious issue is centralisation versus the smaller more isolated communities. The communities I come from constitute a minority group in this country too often not heard. I will offer one area where we have done a terrible disservice to these regions—and I probably will differ with the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), whose speech I was reading in Hansard this morning. I believe fuel tax is the most discriminatory tax in recent Australian history. It attacks those who have no choice but to use fuel, and ignores those who have access to subsidised urban transport in stronger, more viable communities.

I deal now with local government. In the electorate of Grey there are 30 council areas and up to six State electorates. Last week in our non-compulsory local government elections we had an 80 per cent turnout. So I can say that democracy is well and truly alive in my community. I had six valuable and pleasurable years of experience with local government.

Wool and wheat in Grey are our traditional industries. To a large degree this reflects the double standards of Australia. Here we have the free market on the world market compared to the protected wage which can rarely, if ever, reflect the climatic or marketing fluctuations upon which it relies. I am puzzled by the barricade argument on wages when I see variations of factors of three, to five, to 10 in negative to positive incomes in my occupation. These traditional export earners enabled Australia to help pay its way in the world rather than be financed by the international bankers which now finance most of us as well as, of course, the wool industry itself. The rural adjustment scheme is lucky if it helps five per cent of farmers, offers no support for business, and will never be a substitute for effective economic policy.

As I come to my conclusion I want to talk a little bit about political sportsmanship, and a little story that I always enjoyed in recent years. When John Curtin was Prime Minister during the Second World War, a journalist made some snide comment in the presence of Opposition leader Menzies. Apparently Menzies turned on the journalist and defended Curtin with great spirit in view of what Menzies considered an unfair attack. It is stories like that that I think help me to acknowledge the great gift of being born Australian, and it is with a sense of great humility that I remember our pioneers and those parliamentarians that have gone before. I feel particularly fortunate to have witnessed the condolence motions last week for Sir Paul Hasluck and Professor Fred Hollows. At the end of the day we are here to serve, and I look forward to learning and contributing. I thank the House, and I thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Fitzgibbon)—Before I call the honourable member for Bass, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's first speech. I ask the House to extend to her the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mrs Silvia

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker Fitzgibbon. Through you, may I offer my congratulations to my colleagues Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins and the Speaker. I also take this opportunity to congratulate my Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on his win at the 13 March election, thus affording the Australian Labor Party an unprecedented fifth term in government. As the Prime Minister took us through that campaign via One nation and Investing in the nation, I believe he spurred many Australians into a new awareness of themselves and their nation. It is undoubtedly correct to say that there are many more true believers in Australia this day because of his vision and because of his assuredness and true leadership.

PARA.TAB: Thus it is with great pride and humility that I rise in this place to offer this my maiden speech as a true believer of the 37th Parliament of Australia. This is a great moment of triumph for me. I have at last returned the seat of Bass to the Labor Party after its 18 years in the wilderness. The challenge to do so was offered to me at preselection in 1989. The task was a formidable one. However, my predecessor, Warwick Smith, underestimated my tenacity and firm belief that this Smith could win, and today a winner I am. My determination was immovable, although the obstacles were immense. My willingness to strive, my faith and often my pigheadedness kept me from wavering far from the ultimate goal of retrieving the seat of Bass.

My local idol in Bass is Lance Barnard, a former Deputy Prime Minister of this great country. It was he who encouraged and helped me to shape the highway ahead. I made a solemn vow that I would work for three campaigns to get his seat back for the Labor Party. To Lance, if he could see me now, I would say, `Here it is, and by a mere 40 votes'. They say that life begins at 40. Well, here I am at the beginning of a long life in this place, I trust.

My electorate is Bass. It was named after Dr George Bass, an early explorer who, in 1798, circumnavigated Tasmania—then known as Van Diemen's Land—in a small sloop, the Norfolk. Bass Strait was named after him to honour this trip that put Tasmania firmly and well and truly on the map. George Bass was a keen student of nature. It was once said that he was the first man to bring a trained, scientific intelligence to bear upon the natural phenomena of this country. I ask that we heed those ideals today as we all work on both sides of this House to restore our environmental flora and fauna, somewhat similar perhaps to that which Dr Bass must have enjoyed 205 years ago.
The Bass electorate came into being in 1903, and its first member of this House was David Storrer. During his first speech in this Parliament on 2 March 1904 Mr Storrer stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I am one of those who favour the idea that the Federal authorities should take over the whole of the functions of government and thus do away with the necessity for incurring expense in maintaining State Parliaments.

It seems that this man was well ahead in his thinking. Yet, almost 90 years later, we are still considering the possibility of one tier of government instead of what we now have, possibly an overgoverning of our people. Way back then David Storrer showed major concerns with the amount of commodities we were importing from foreign countries. He said that Australia in the early 1900s was intent on building up overseas industries and giving employment to their workers instead of affording encouragement and employment to the men and women of our own nation. Mayhap we should reflect a while on this thought as being once again perhaps relevant to today's import-export imbalance. His solution to partially avoid this imbalance in 1904 was to levy higher duties—today's tariffs—upon foreign goods imported, although I may add he did not suggest putting them on goods from Great Britain. Is this another suggestion from the past for us to heed?

PARA.TAB: Until today, the Labor Party has held the seat of Bass on and off for 57 out of 90 years, with its most famous ALP members being Claude Barnard and his son Lance, my mentor. I look to serving the electorate of Bass beyond the turn of the century at the very least. Claude Barnard held the seat from 1934 to 1949. He was a locomotive engineman and, during his service in this place, chaired the Joint Committee on Social Security and was Minister for Repatriation. On leaving this place he was elected to the House of Assembly in Tasmania. His son Lance was elected in 1954 and served in many ministerial positions, including health, repatriation, primary industry, immigration, the interior, labour and national service, supply, Navy, Army and Defence, and went on to be Deputy Prime Minister from December 1972 until his retirement in June 1974. Lance was and is an extremely articulate gentleman and a wonderful person to model oneself upon. May I be half as good as he, and I will have achieved much. Today he continues to steadfastly work with our veterans with an immense knowledge and understanding of the problems they still face. I too will continue to make representation on their behalf.

Bass is one of five electorates in Tasmania, and may I be parochial enough to say the most beautiful. It is a provincial one, covering approximately 7,254 square kilometres. It runs from Launceston in the south to Flinders Island in the north. Its major and only city is Launceston, my home town. Bass then wanders up the western side of the Tamar River to Legana and along the whole of the eastern river bank to George Town where the Seacat of Tasmania brings tourists from that large island to the north to visit us. The electorate then spreads up through the north-eastern rural sector taking in Lilydale, Gladstone, Scottsdale, Derby and Ringarooma, and offshore to Cape Barron and Clarke and Flinders Islands. Bass shares its boundaries with the sprawling electorate of my colleague the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Adams).

The physical features of Bass are beautiful and boundless, from such spectacular mountains as Ben Lomond and Strezlecki, through shady fern glades near Derby to the beautiful Lilydale and Columbus Falls. Then, in Launceston, we find the spectacular Cataract Gorge and the Cliff Grounds. On down the Tamar, we go to the glorious beaches and the bays of the northern coastline which extend from Low Head through Bridport and Weymouth along to Little Musselroe Bay, formerly called Lyme Regis. Products and industries of the area include farming, fishing, winemaking, textiles, aluminium and ferrous metals, wood, woodchips, timber, meat and vegetable production, boatbuilding, a brewery and tourism.

At this time I desire to express my deep gratitude to the voters of my electorate who have put their faith in me. They have given me this opportunity to serve as their member in the 37th Parliament of Australia. I assure them that I realise the honour that they have afforded me, and I will not let them down. I also stand here as the first Tasmanian Labor woman to be elected to the House of Representatives and follow only one other woman in Tasmania to this House, Dame Enid Lyons. There has been a 42-year drought of women from Tasmania in the House of Representatives, but the drought now has broken.

My thanks also go to my colleagues Senators Margaret Reynolds, Graham Richardson, Michael Tate, Nick Sherry and Terry Aulich, as well as the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones), the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) and the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) for their support and encouragement over the last five years. To my mother, Lucie Cruse, I give thanks for her encouragement and direction to do my own thing, to achieve my goals. To my sister, Wendy, and her sons, Douglas and Damien, for their assistance through two campaigns and for the moral support when the road was tough, I thank you. To my campaign team members, Charles, Sue Adrian and Tony, many thanks; and to my manager, Alan Stacey, and his wife, Christine, who totally believed in my ability, who encouraged me continuously and who showed me the way through the dark days of two campaigns and constantly gave their total commitment, I will always be indebted.

My thanks also go to Jack, my long-suffering husband of 32 years, who proudly sits in the gallery this evening. I thank him for tolerating my extremes, for understanding my ambitions and for learning to cook, wash and iron for himself in the last few years. My eternal gratitude and love go to him. Perhaps it is in line to offer apologies to my youngest daughter, Bindi, for not always being there for her, but I extend to her my thanks for her support and love. To my eldest daughter, Tamsyn, who always believed that I was destined to take my seat in this place: thank you for being another true believer.

I extend further gratitude to the branch members of Bass, particularly Maureen and the Lilydale branch members, and also to the ladies of ALPS, which is the Australian Labor Party Sisterhood. I believe it to be the only one now in existence in Australia. I also extend my gratitude to all the unions for their support, particularly the men of the Seamen's Union, and to the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) and his office members who have unstintingly given of their time and efforts to assist me along the way. I pay tribute to all their dedication in working with me towards this—the ultimate goal. With faith and dedication I offer to them a strong and positive voice in Canberra, a voice to lobby for what they believe in, a voice to be heard in this place on their behalf.

I turn now to the tasks I see ahead for me in my electorate—and there are several. Firstly comes the task of improving employment opportunities. There are many people in my electorate who have suggested many methods for alleviating this problem. Therefore, may I suggest that this Government should form a task force that could appropriately glean the information from all people Australia-wide who have ideas—and there are many, I know.

We must continue the process of reform that has been occurring in all areas of our nation's economy over the last 10 years. As my colleague the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) espoused last week, we have put many reforms in place throughout industry, the financial market and the business sector, and this must continue. These policies and reforms will enable us to become more performance orientated and thus more competitive with overseas markets, ultimately offering more employment opportunities for our men and women.

Our performance in trading offshore has markedly improved and we have at last shifted from a `living off the sheep's back' mentality to being far-sighted and imaginative with our ideas. There are statistics abounding to show us these successes. In over 10 years we have seen a huge 193 per cent growth in exports, which represents a growth in GDP of 14 per cent to 23 per cent by 1992. Our industry base is improving with labour productivity growing continuously.

From 1993 and beyond the Labor Government will continue these major reforms with a national training initiative to improve competencies for government buyers in the education process and research development. Quality assurance is another initiative aimed at promoting a more competitive industry. Rationalisation and amalgamation of our 300-plus trade unions into a more manageable structure of about 20 national unions will be a dramatic step but, in my estimate, an acknowledgment of a process of change towards unification and a stronger industrial base with which to expand and grow once again into a major world player.

It is also pleasing to note in today's Australian that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) reaffirmed the Government's intention to retain awards as a safety net, coupled with a new set of minimum standards under a collective bargaining system, rather than individual contracts. Thus, the rights of workers will always be safeguarded by a third person negotiating on their behalf and with their input.

As the growing public debate has shown, the notion that Australia should become a republic is attracting a growing number of interested people. I have noted that in the speeches this evening. Just recently I attended an RSL dinner in Launceston where a majority appeared committed to a purely Australian identity—much to my surprise. There seemed to be a little hesitation, however, about major changes to the flag. It is also interesting to note that in 1977, when a coalition government conducted a national poll to choose a purely Australian national song, a total of 5,113,296 people chose either Advance Australia Fair, Song of Australia or Waltzing Matilda, as opposed to 1,182,689 for God Save the Queen. I wonder what a similar poll would reveal on today's subject of becoming a republic. We may get a big surprise! I also noted in today's Herald-Sun that in another 18 years or so there will be one more little monarchist in the opposition ranks. Where is the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer)?

Mr Speaker, since Federation and since our coming to this part of the world in 1788 we have changed from a British, convict based nation to a diverse, multicultural nation, interlinked with an age-old indigenous race of people—our Aboriginals. It is time for our own identity. It is time for another beginning. It is time to be truly Australian. Let us look objectively at our Prime Minister's vision of the unification of Federal and State industrial relations, of reconciliation with our Aboriginal people, of a better way of life for all Australians, no matter from which corner of the globe they came. Let us unite and build a new Australia, a better Australia, a stronger and richer Australia for all the generations that will follow us.

Another factor I would mention here is the Prime Minister's 1992 environment statement which identified sustainable management of water resources as a major issue of the 1990s. The $40 million initiative over four years will directly improve water quality in river and catchment areas around Australia. This initiative will allow governments and local communities to tackle key sources of pollution such as sewage plants and algal problems in the Murray-Darling basin in particular. In urban areas possible projects could be stormwater management and waste water disposal. The national landcare program is the most far-reaching program a federal government has ever undertaken and the Government is to be applauded for its initiative.

Launceston is situated at the confluence of the Tamar and North and South Esk rivers and has a system of levees to protect the central business district and surrounding residential and industrial properties. The levees are founded on silt; thus settlement and subsidence have occurred which now requires major remedial works. Launceston has been lucky enough to get some of the assistance through landcare to the tune of $440,447. Major structural reforms of the underground systems have been ongoing for some years and this government assistance, through landcare, has helped. I am assured that many other places in Australia are being helped as well to sustain environmental protection.

Briefly, I would now like to commend to this Government the notion of our Bass Strait becoming an integrated part of the national highway system of Australia. It is not by choice that water separates us from the mainland and I will proffer throughout my term here the idea that this particular piece of water becomes part of the national highway system in this country.

Mr Deputy Speaker, before closing I wish to draw attention to the record number of women now in this House: 13 in total. This indeed is reflective of how attitudes are changing, but parity is still a long way off. As we head towards a republic, we note that the Labor Party is still the only party conducive to ensuring that women do have a vital say in the formulation of government policy via their affirmative action policy, and this is to be applauded.
Finally, I draw the House's attention to some of the words of our national song which I ask everyone seated here to heed. Verses one and two, only part thereof, say:

SPEECH.PARA: We've golden soil and wealth for toil
Our home is girt by sea
Our land abounds in nature's gifts
Of beauty rich and rare
For those who've come across the seas
We've boundless plains to share
With courage let us all combine
To advance Australia fair.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Fitzgibbon)—Order! Before I call the honourable member for Lyne, I remind the House that it is the honourable member's first speech and I ask that honourable members pay him the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. To represent the seat of Lyne in the Commonwealth Parliament is an honour and a privilege and I am delighted to be here in this House. Like every other member, I owe my presence here to a great many people. Firstly, may I acknowledge the fantastic support of my wife, Wendy, and my three daughters, Terri, Prue and Sarah, as well as both our parents.

PARA.TAB: I must thank the electors of Lyne who have chosen me to represent them and their interests in this place. I am their servant and the servant of the electorate. I also thank my National Party of Australia supporters both within the electorate and elsewhere, including my federal leader, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), and my deputy leader, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson). I would also like to thank my Federal and State parliamentary colleagues who assisted me with what was an exciting and a very tough campaign. The one person whom I must acknowledge and for whom I put my sincere appreciation on record is Mr Bruce Cowan, the former member for Lyne, who not only did a magnificent job as my campaign director, but also during his 13 years as the member for Lyne represented all his constituents in an exemplary manner.

Mr Deputy Speaker, it has become very evident to me that Bruce Cowan was held in high regard within the Parliament by all honourable members on both sides of this House as well as the staff of the Parliament. I know all honourable members as well as the constituents of Lyne would join with me in congratulating Bruce for his distinguished career in both the New South Wales State House and in this, the Commonwealth Parliament.

I am a member of the National Party of Australia, as have been the three previous members who have represented the seat of Lyne with distinction. Mr Jim Eggins of the former Australian Country Party was the first member to represent Lyne from 1949 until his untimely death in 1952. Following this, in 1952 Mr Phillip E. Lucock of the National Country Party won the by-election and held the seat until his retirement in 1980, during which time he represented the Parliament at the United Nations and elsewhere, as well as serving in the high office of Deputy Speaker of the House of Representatives for over 12 years. Bruce Cowan then held the seat from 1980 until he retired on 13 March this year. Following these three great Australians, it was with a great deal of pride that on 4 May 1993 I was sworn in as the fourth member to represent the seat of Lyne.

The electorate of Lyne is named after Sir William Lyne, a former premier of New South Wales and a founding member of this Parliament, who held the seat of Hume at its inception in 1901. In current debate on republicanism, I get a sense that history does repeat itself when it is discovered that Sir William Lyne played a central role in the debate leading up to Federation in 1901. In fact, I identify closely with the man when I see him described as:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a home-loving man, he liked the races, and he was fond of a first class concert. He occasionally went to the theatre and when he read anything it was usually a magazine!

My electorate of Lyne is bounded by the electorates of Cowper and New England in the north, and Paterson in the west and south. Geographically the electorate of Lyne covers an area of 5,200 square kilometres from the Hastings River in the north to the twin towns of Forster-Tuncurry in the south, and inland to the western boundary of the Greater Taree City Council area, and includes the major centres of Port Macquarie, Taree, Forster-Tuncurry, Wingham, Wauchope, Laurieton, North Haven, Bonny Hills, Lake Cathie, Old Bar, Comboyne, Harrington, and Kendall. There are three major centres of population, and along with an impressive growth rate, Port Macquarie, Taree, and Forster-Tuncurry are burdened with higher than the national average rates of unemployment and, in particular, youth unemployment.

PARA.TAB: Mr Deputy Speaker, during the recent campaign in the lead-up to the federal election in March we flagged at every opportunity the devastating impact that unemployment was having on our society and, in particular, the electorate of Lyne. I noted with interest the absence of any positive proposals in the Governor-General's address to tackle our chronic, long-term unemployment problem which the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) has stated will rise to well over 400,000 in the next year. Nor was there any action plan to reduce our exploding foreign debt.The republican debate is not going to generate any jobs for my unemployed constituents. They are more interested in getting meaningful, long-term employment than in whether we have a governor-general or a president.

Historically, the regional economy in Lyne has been centred around primary industries such as dairying, beef, fishing and oyster farming, as well as the harvesting of natural resources such as timber. Although these industries are still important to the regional economy, the development of the tourism industry and the dramatic increase in the retired population, as well as widespread rationalisation of these rural industries, has seen a shift in the economic base of the region. An interesting example of that rationalisation and its effect on local employment is in the dairying industry. In the last 10 years in New South Wales the dairy industry has seen the number of dairy farmers fall by 40 per cent with the number of producing cows falling by 15 per cent, yet the amount of milk produced increasing by approximately 40 per cent.

It is important to note here that my electorate of Lyne is changing dramatically. It was once considered a solely rural region, and although it still has a sound rural base it is now diversifying into a region with a strong industry and business component. My ambition for the electorate of Lyne is to see it become a strategic location for regional development. We already have a large cross-section of manufacturing industries of world standard which are earning export dollars for Australia within our region. They have recognised the potential of our stable labour market, the availability of ever improving infrastructure and our strategic location between the major cities of Sydney and Brisbane.

It was with a great deal of interest that I learnt of the regional development strategy developed by the Country Mayors Association of New South Wales which is being launched in Sydney on 21 May this year. Also of interest was the funding of that scheme which was partly funded by the Department of Employment, Education and Training under the OLMA program. Giving credit where credit is due, the Government should be commended for the introduction of the OLMA program. There is not only that program which the Country Mayors Association has put together, but in my electorate of Lyne another very successful enterprise has been developed through this program which is a cooperative of herb and flower growers who are developing an export market for fresh flowers and orchids in the USA. These are the niche markets we must encourage our people to explore and get into.

I also commend the Government for creating the portfolio of regional development in the current Keating Ministry and I ask the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Mr Griffiths) when formulating strategies to consider not just the Latrobe Valley in Victoria and the Hunter Valley in New South Wales but also to give consideration to the Manning and Hastings valleys on the mid-north coast of New South Wales.

A large number of our existing industries could employ more and would export more if a little understanding and consideration were shown by government. If we can spend millions of taxpayers' dollars on waterfront redundancies, why can we not give more consideration to government support for research and development programs, low interest start-up loans and short-term loans for expansion programs? We have a flourishing vineyard and winery at Port Macquarie leading the way with new technology, exporting 30 per cent of its production. Yet the famous Cassegrain family vineyards are pedalling their own canoe as far as research and development is concerned. Why should government not support export industries which are creating employment as they grow and develop larger niche markets.

At this stage I should like to mention a number of companies which have undertaken quality assurance programs in an attempt to improve the efficiency of their businesses and move towards world standard practices. Anvic Meat Exports Pty Ltd of Wingham, which exports the majority of its throughput to Japan, America and Korea, and Port Macquarie Slipways Pty Ltd, which is a major supplier to the Department of Defence, have expended thousands of dollars on these quality assurance programs but are yet to see the real benefits from these improvements. The question must be asked: when will the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) undertake a complete review of AQIS and rationalise the meat inspection service in Australia? So far as Port Macquarie Slipways is concerned, why is quality assurance accreditation a pre-tender requirement for the Navy, yet the Australian Army will not recognise this accreditation? Surely the Government should be leading the way in this regard.

The town of Taree has special prominence in the Lyne electorate as a major manufacturing centre, with a variety of firms having decentralised to the area over the past 20 years. Whilst many companies such as Jockey Australia, Stebercraft, Britax Brylite and Lansdowne Engineering have successfully decentralised to my electorate, an active federal government program to encourage further regional development is needed.

The arguments for regional development and associated settlement expansion within my own electorate are compelling. Unemployment figures in my electorate are, on average, five per cent higher than the national average, signifying a very stable labour force. As well, transport and communications infrastructures are so advanced today that contact with all major centres can be maintained easily.

There are many ways to begin to address the imbalance and distortion in population and investment and to increase economic and employment opportunities throughout regional Australia. It needs to be recognised that the tasks need to be spread over the three tiers of government and through the private sector.

A plan for settlement and infrastructure needs to be developed. This plan needs to identify, prioritise and coordinate strategic State and Commonwealth infrastructure, particularly road, rail, air and education. The plan also needs to develop an achievable goal for decentralisation. For example, a starting point should be to try to achieve the diversion away from metropolitan centres of up to one million people over the next 25 years.

The establishment of a regional industries incentive fund needs to take place. Such a fund could build up to $200 million per annum from Commonwealth, State and local government sources. These funds could be used to encourage relocation, expansion or start-ups of country industry with export potential or import substitution, particularly in areas of competitive advantage, for example, food, fibre and minerals processing. Previous mechanisms, such as payroll tax rebates and loan guarantees with sunset clauses and delivery through existing funds management network could also be used. Industry incentives in the country should partly replace housing subsidies in the city.

The promotion of metropolitan industry that can benefit from a country location needs to take place. This would help to achieve grouping of industry in regional centres so that by encouraging one industry to decentralise a whole range of secondary industries will also decentralise. Within New South Wales, the New South Wales Department of Agriculture and the Police Academy have decentralised and are two examples of successful relocation.

Regional expansion of education facilities must be encouraged. University expansion should be encouraged through expanded funding and the creation of extra places. The wider use of telecommunications products should be promoted as well as the active involvement of local communities.

Further federal funding for decentralisation assistance needs to occur. The Chamber of Manufactures of New South Wales noted in a recent study on industry relocation that the distinct lack of interest shown by manufacturers in moving to non-metropolitan New South Wales is of significant concern to State and Commonwealth regional development objectives. Indeed, statistics show that only 1.3 per cent of firms were even considering moving to a non-metropolitan location in New South Wales under current economic policies. With government incentives regional development will benefit not only the industries concerned but also the regional economy and indeed the national economy.

I mention regional development today in my maiden speech as I feel it is an untapped resource within our great nation's economic regrowth. My electorate has unrestricted potential for growth and development. Yet incentives need to be provided to break the ice and kill the perception that regional means isolated.

One industry that has thrived within my electorate without much government support is the tourism industry. It contributes in excess of $350 million to the region's economy and in particular the economy of Port Macquarie and Forster-Tuncurry. We must continue to focus on this important industry and provide the necessary reforms for it to continue growing and competing. It was pleasing to hear of the positive move on penalty rates in the tourism industry. These changes will allow more flexibility for employers and employees.

The electorate of Lyne has an abundance of tourist attractions including many famous beaches, seaside ports and historical and natural attractions. I am sure that most honourable members here this evening would have at some stage in their lives enjoyed holidays in the area that boasts Australia's best climate. If any honourable member has not experienced this region, well, I can certainly help arrange a lovely mid-north coast holiday for him or her!

After emphasising the importance of tourism to the region, I turn to the issue of roads, and in particular to the serious concern within my electorate over the state of the Pacific Highway. Our tourism industry is one which relies almost entirely on road transport into and out of the area. Likewise, our regional development program relies enormously on having an efficient and safe transport infrastructure based around road transport. Yet it concerns me greatly that I now have to follow the trend set by all previous members for Lyne when making their maiden speeches in this House by having to put on record my concerns about the poor quality of this major highway which is carrying an increasing volume of traffic all the time.

In February this year the New South Wales Roads and Traffic Authority released a report on the north coast road structure which found that nearly 40 per cent of the north coast road network is in only a fair to poor condition; that is, 40 per cent of the region's roads are in an unsuitable condition for modern transport needs. The lives of ordinary Australians are being placed in jeopardy due to the lack of concern about the Pacific Highway.
