TALK.START.PARA: —I just hope that the previous speaker, the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Aldred) has got his facts right. I am very pleased to rise tonight on this side of the House. The good guys have won again and it is very pleasing to see that the Labor Party has won an historic fifth term. I am also very pleased to have the opportunity to support these appropriation and supply Bills and to talk generally about some of the positive initiatives that this Government is implementing.

PARA.TAB: May I congratulate the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker and all the new members who were elected at the last election. Listening to their maiden speeches, one can only say that this crop of new members is undoubtedly rich in ability and talent. I do not think there is any doubt about that. I refer particularly to those new members on this side of the House.

I suppose one could single out many of them, but in particular I very much enjoyed the maiden speech of my house friend—we share a house together—the honourable member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) and the excellent contribution this afternoon of my very good friend and colleague the honourable member for Lilley (Mr Swan). That is not in any way to denigrate the speeches made by many of my colleagues here today. They were all excellent and they deserve to be congratulated.

These appropriation and supply Bills comprise Additional Estimates for 1992-93. We are talking about, in words as used in the Telecom advertisements, money for emergency relief, our CES network, implementation of the Mayer report and the employment incentive scheme. We are talking about child care fee relief, defence housing, the employer component of superannuation and our extremely successful labour market programs. We are also talking about the continuation of good government. We feel good on this side of the House. We feel good because we are experiencing the celebration of the Australian Labor Party and the broader labour movement.

In my own electorate, local party members worked with great passion and skill to ensure that we retained government. On this first occasion that I have had to speak in a debate such as this, I want to take this opportunity to thank all my campaign team, particularly all the branch members in my electorate of Bowman, who worked so hard to make sure that I was returned as the member, and also to make sure that we were returned as a government.

It would not be correct of me not to mention the fantastic contributions made by people such as Joan Budd, my campaign manager; her husband, John Budd, who is my FDE president, and the local member for Redlands; and my very good friend and colleague Jim Elder, Minister for Business, Industry and Regional Development in Queensland, along with the Deputy Premier, Tom Burns, and Darryl Briskey, the member for Cleveland, who are all excellent members. I am very proud to say that every State member in my electorate is from the Labor Party—part of the good guys.

However, to my mind there was an even more pleasing aspect of the election result and that was the re-election of the Labor Government, because it also celebrates the good judgment of the Australian people. The Australian people rejected the throwback that was Fightback. They rejected the Opposition's regressive, iniquitous, divisive, foreign inspired and econometric model driven grab bag of new right cure-alls. They rejected them in favour of Labor's fairer, more compassionate, more understanding and, most of all, more Australian policies.

It seems that the Liberal and National parties have since dropped the centrepiece of their inequitable policies, the goods and services tax. At least in the case of the GST, the Opposition got the message that the Australian people sent it on 13 March. It has, however, hung onto a policy that was equally rejected by the electorate, and that is its entirely unpalatable industrial relations policy. It is the area of industrial relations that exemplifies how un-Australian the Opposition's policies are. Basically, it is an imported product from New Zealand, I guess with a bit of American seasoning. Australians did not want individual employment contracts imposed on them. Handing over total workplace power to the employer, thankfully, is still a largely alien concept in this country.

As others here realise, in some parts of the Commonwealth ordinary working Australians are currently having their jobs played around with by unscrupulous employers and, unfortunately, in some cases even compliant State governments. In Victoria, the Kennett Government pushes on with its industrial chaos legislation. While the Australians in my own electorate are lucky enough to enjoy the industrial harmony that is encouraged by the Federal and State Labor governments, they are currently being threatened by an attempt to introduce, by stealth, individual work contracts for young people.

The perpetrator of this so-called scheme is a Mr Graeme Haycroft and his Troubleshooters Available organisation. Honourable members, especially those from Victoria and Queensland, will undoubtedly have heard of him. Controversy seems to have followed him across the country—from the building sites of Melbourne, via the shearing sheds of western Queensland, and onto his latest venture. Graeme Haycroft has of late been promoting what he calls the youth contract workers scheme. I will, however, call it as I see it, namely, a cheap labour scheme. It cannot be seen as anything less.

It is Mr Haycroft's stated intention that the scheme is designed to bypass and undercut the award system—the award system that has particularly protected the vulnerable in the workplace. Fundamentally, this contract labour scheme offers young people no protection from unscrupulous employers. It now appears to be Mr Haycroft's intention to import this scheme into my local Redland shire. He has conned the local Chamber of Commerce into supporting him. I find this most disappointing, to say the least, and I ask it to reconsider that support. One thing for sure is that it will get no support from me on this matter. I am here to tell Mr Haycroft that he is just not wanted in my electorate.

Just as the Australian electorate rejected the offer of lower wages and conditions, particularly the $3 per hour youth wage, the young people of my electorate will turn down this dubious offer of assistance by a dubious scheme. This youth contract workers scheme has been running on Queensland's Sunshine Coast for a few months. The young unemployed people of that area are, very intelligently, avoiding the scheme.

Every member of this House is aware of the gravity of our youth unemployment problem. I am not down on the enthusiastic young people who want to work. The significant difference between myself and Haycroft is that I support, and I believe the general Australian community supports, the programs that the Government already has in place to assist the young unemployed. That is why a significant part of these Bills before the House is pumping more well-targeted money into these extremely effective programs. Before he gets too keen on proposing the setting up of his scheme in the Redlands, Mr Haycroft should have a look around at what training is already available for our young people.

The Commonwealth Government has substantial schemes that take a productive approach to helping young people find meaningful employment. There are subsidised apprenticeships, traineeships, and currently teenagers who have been unemployed for six months have access to accredited vocational training. These teenagers also get their jobstart card which alerts their potential employers that there is a wage subsidy available to help them with the cost of employing the teenagers.

There is a great deal of assistance very evidently available for the unemployed in my electorate. They, like other unemployed people in my area, are very professionally and compassionately assisted in the quest for work by the staff of the local Cleveland and Wynnum Commonwealth Employment Service offices, which do an excellent job in placing people. These CES offices place hundreds of young people in employment. I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and honourable members present to compare that record with that of Mr Haycroft's contract scheme. From my information, only a small number have got work on the Sunshine Coast—that is, work at $4.15 per hour with no safety net or conditions and training of dubious quality.

The Government already supports the local skillshare organisations. Training venues such as this are the way our local young people improve their ability to enter the work force and stay in an interesting job for the long term. Rest assured, Mr Deputy Speaker, I will not rest until Graeme Haycroft realises that people are not interested in his fly-by-night contract labour schemes. They are nothing but a cruel hoax and offer young people only false hope and slave wages—and of course give them also a false hope for the future.

Labor's caring outlook is not directed only at young Australians. There is a lot of talk about this country's ageing population, and it is Labor's policies that help these older Australians to live in comfort and with some dignity. In my role as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security, I take great pride in the assistance we in Australia afford our age pensioners. The extension of fringe benefits, funded through these Bills, is only one good example. I mention at this stage that some concern is being whipped up in the pensioner community mainly by financial planners who obviously see one area of their business affected, namely, the treatment of shares for income purposes as and from September 1993.

Indeed, I notice that at the end of last year although the Opposition in the Senate voted for this measure, which is now law—and it does not matter how much the Opposition says it did not; it did—obviously for the purposes of trying to gain some political points, the Opposition in the Senate is now combining with the Australian Democrats to bring in a private member's Bill. The Opposition is also saying that the Government's treatment of shares is wrong and so on.

We believe the social security system is basically a needs based system which is there to help those people who need it. The savings, which could be as high as $80 million for an initial setting up cost of some $350,000, have allowed the Government as and from 1 April 1993 to extend the fringe benefits to everyone who has a part or full pension. I know from talking to the many thousands of age pensioners and pensioners generally throughout the country that they place a very high value on those fringe benefits.

Some three per cent of pensioners have money to invest in shares, in many cases simply to circumvent the income tax test. If it means that they have to be brought back to the same situation as other managed investments in order to find the appropriate funds in these tough economic times to extend fringe benefits to everybody, that is not a high price to pay. I look forward to the debate coming to this House so that we can talk about this matter at greater length. I can assure the Opposition that this is something which the Government supports very strongly. The Opposition supported it. I cannot see why those opposite should suddenly change their minds, but that is something we will examine later.

Dignity is terribly important for older Australians. Older Australians do not want to have to rely on others all the time—they want to do some things for themselves and at their own pace. In this situation, what can seem a very trivial matter may make the everyday experiences painful and frustrating.

A very community minded resident in my electorate, Mr Dennis Neville, who also happens to be a senior journalist at the local newspapers, the Redland Times and the Bayside Bulletin, brought to my attention recently the frustration that many older people experience just trying to open everyday household products. People, whose hands may not be as strong and dexterous as they used to be, find it very difficult opening certain items that they buy from the supermarket. Difficulty with packaging is a widespread problem. Some of the items that are commonly complained about include bottles of food products, cereal packets, most items packed in plastic, and cleaning items.

Household chemicals pose a particular problem. Many of these items have childproof lids which can require a great deal of dexterity and strength. This issue becomes particularly alarming when one hears that some very frustrated older people enlist the aid of sharp knives making the opening of simple, everyday products a dangerous exercise.

I will be raising this issue with the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Mrs McHugh) to see whether we can alert manufacturers to the problems being experienced. I am certain that once manufacturers become aware of the extent of the problem they would consider an investigation into their respective packaging policies. If we here, and those in industry, can do something to alleviate the problems that older Australians experience, we as a nation are only living up to the standard that has already been set by this Government—a standard of caring and compassion for senior citizens of this country.

These Bills before the House tonight are essential for the continuation of good government in Australia. Moneys from these Bills are needed to continue the highly successful community development employment projects within Aboriginal communities, to fund the National Railways Commission, to fund the transfer to the States of the repatriation general hospitals, and to fund an equity contribution to the AOTC. I, look forward—as I am sure do all colleagues on this side of the House—to the challenges of the next three years of government; continuing the reforming policies that are the trademark of the Labor Party and the reason for our success.

I notice that I will be followed shortly in this debate by the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper), a legal colleague of mine who I know has not been a member of this House for six years. I wish him well, but not too well, because he is a member of a party that has a lot of problems—

A number of observations, however, about the new home of the Parliament are in order. The new House is impressive—cleverly designed and incorporating many unique features. The 22 kilometres of corridors, however, are enough to render the gymnasium redundant. Sadly, the colours throughout the building, particularly in the two chambers, seem faded. Their pale, insipid and washed-out appearance is a parody of the rich and vivid green and red tonings of the former House of Representatives and Senate chambers. One can only hope that when refurbishment is required this mistake will be rectified.

Somehow the building lacks much symbolism and what little there is is obscure and must be elaborately explained to be fully understood. The royal arms is absent, the flag in this chamber is an afterthought and our Commonwealth crest is almost hidden in the ceiling. Did the designers seek to gut our heritage, our political origins and 200 years of proud history?

I am saddened that the Speaker's chair, that gift from the Mother of Parliaments at Westminster, has been left to rot in a constitutional museum. Surely the architect's billion dollar budget could have extended to providing this unique national treasure with a new home where it belongs? This error or omission must be rectified upon our return to government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Mabo decision does nothing to improve relations between Aboriginals and non-Aboriginals. The judgment of the High Court of Australia has discouraged investment in a whole range of areas—in the pastoral industry and in mining and tourism—and concern is continuing to mount. The impact on our economy will be devastating. While some say that the Mabo decision was a narrow one, based on its particular facts, and that the only land caught in the net will be certain isolated parts of the nation, this has not been proven. Even if that view is currently correct, uncertainty remains for the court may, at any time, expand the extent of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander title. Indeed, much of Australia could ultimately be trapped.

PARA.TAB: Most agree that the full ramifications of Mabo are unclear. The Government itself has promised to fund, at our expense, a number of cases to test its limits. Negotiation has been suggested, but this will not resolve the legal mire. The last thing Australia needs is the year in, year out debilitating effect of protracted litigation. We would never really know the final extent of Mabo because the next case would be just around the corner. Racial harmony, jobs, including Aboriginal jobs, investment and economic recovery would all be casualties.

There have been calls for legislation to bring certainty back into the land law. Industry groups, prospective overseas investors, both sides of politics, the Queensland Labor Premier and Aboriginal people themselves have all canvassed this possibility.

The most clear, decisive and desirable action would be complementary State and Federal legislation to reverse Mabo. Alternatively, the Federal Parliament could amend its own laws, where they have contributed to the ability of the court to find in favour of Mabo. This would not be an approach inconsistent with the concept of land rights, as the States could then deal with this issue in accordance with their own laws and values. While the Parliament would have then seized the initiative to break the deadlock, boosting stability, investment and jobs, we, as members of Parliament, are at least accountable at every election to the community for our actions. Unfortunately, the unelected politicians of the High Court are accountable to no-one.

In the minutes remaining to me—not very many minutes—I will refer briefly to one or two other matters. I think it is wrong that we have compulsory voting in this nation. I think if we believe in democracy we should give people the right to vote or not to vote. I also would like to place on record my very strong support for our Australian flag. I think our Australian flag is a symbol of our nation of which we are all justly proud. I repeat the pledge made in my maiden speech:
I intend to serve my electorate, my State and this Parliament to the best of my ability in the tradition of my predecessors so that I may be considered and counted worthy to be their successor.

SPEECH.PARA: I endeavoured to carry out this pledge. At that time I adopted the words of Sir Winston Churchill, who said:
This is not the end, it is not even the beginning of the end, but it is perhaps the end of the beginning.
That was in 1985. Tonight, Mr Speaker, however is a new beginning. I thank the House.
